ID Name Text
1 Scope The primary application of this guide is to serve as the basis for MPM signal interface (e.g., MPM to payload C&DH interface, MPM to Host System, and MPM A to MPM B interface) and performance commonality. This guide recommends the MPM house a single-thread unit, where two physically separate MPM units would be installed into the satellite. However, a contractor may prefer to develop an MPM where the primary and redundant units are contained within a single housing. Also, there may be different MPM configurations for different missions. For example, where the amount of shielding provided by the MPM housing differs between mission type/environmental applications. Furthermore, this specification recommends provisions for a spare SpaceVPX module slot in the MPMs Basic and Switch portions, where both are envisioned to accommodate future cyber interface/processing capabilities and/or special application unique interface accommodations.

3 Requirements No Text Found
3.1 MPM General Description The MOSA Payload Manager (MPM) is derived from the IEEE-ISTO MOSA Payload Manager Standard (MOSA-IF-S-002). The primary responsibilities of the MPM are to conduct and manage payload command and data handling (C&DH) related transactions, support payload fault-management (except power control), provide a common local area network for payloads, enable secure high-speed communication between authorized payloads, and provide resources for intra-vehicle threat protection. Payload management functions include commanding the Payloads, obtaining and processing telemetry from each Payload, detecting the health status of Payloads, and placing Payloads into their various Modes (e.g., reset, standby, operational, contingency). Examples of planned inter-vehicle threat protection and resilience include proven software-based rapid detection of out-of-family or potentially rogue commands; and, provisions for two spare SpaceVPX 6U module slots (one in the Basic-portion & one in the Switch-portion) for a user-provided SpaceVPX compliant payload module to perform special (e.g., cyber, high-speed processing, and/or custom interface adaptation) functions. For a general description of the MPM placement within the envisioned architecture see Figure 1.
3.2 General Requirements This section contains general requirements applicable across multiple other paragraphs that typically include additional detail relative to that paragraph topic.
3.2.1 Interface Architecture No Text Found
3.2.1.1 Interface Types No Text Found
3.2.1.1.1 MPM Input Power The MPM includes a Basic-portion and a Switch-portion, each will separately receive input power with the same input voltage range (24 VDC 105 VDC). In the event that the MPM must enter into a low power Mode (e.g., a satellite safe Mode condition) it will be feasible to keep the Basic-portion active while the Switch-portion (which can be a high-power consumer) has power removed.
3.2.1.1.1.1 No Text Found The MPM Basic-portion should operate over an input voltage range of 24 VDC to 105 VDC.
3.2.1.1.1.2 No Text Found The MPM Basic-portion should accept separate, current limited, switched primary power from the Host System.
3.2.1.1.1.3 No Text Found The MPM Switch-portion should operate over an input voltage range of 24 VDC to 105 VDC.
3.2.1.1.1.4 No Text Found The MPM Switch-portion should accept separate, current limited, switched primary power from the Host System.
3.2.1.1.2 Passive Analog (Resistive) A passive analog signal is an output from the MPM (typically serving as a direct interface with the Host System) and accommodates a resistive sensor such as a thermistor (e.g., S-311-P-18, dash number 5 (i.e., 5K ohm @ 25 degrees Celsius (ambient temperature))).
3.2.1.1.2.1 No Text Found A Passive Analog (Resistive) signal should provide a resistive impedance ranging from 1190K Ohms to 425 Ohms.
3.2.1.1.2.2 No Text Found The Passive Analog (Resistive) signal should provide 5K Ohms resistance at ambient temperature (i.e., 25 degrees Celsius).
3.2.1.1.3 Active Analog An active analog signal is an output from the MPM (typically serving as a direct interface with the Host System or use in conjunction with its MPM fault management functions) providing an analog output voltage between +10 and 10 VDC.
3.2.1.1.3.1 No Text Found An Active Analog output signal should provide a maximum voltage range between +10 VDC and -10 VDC.
3.2.1.1.3.2 No Text Found Each Active analog signal should be a single-ended signal, with a return.
3.2.1.1.3.3 No Text Found Each non-return Active Analog signal should have a series resistance of 10k ohm between its interface connector pin and its internal signal source.
3.2.1.1.3.4 No Text Found The load resistance of each Active Analog signal input should be a minimum of 1 Mega-Ohms.
3.2.1.1.3.5 No Text Found The load capacitance of each Active Analog signal input should be a maximum of 200 pico-Farad shunt capacitance.
3.2.1.1.4 Discrete Signal Interface The Discrete Signal Interface signal type is used by the MPM (along with its application-interfaces: Host System and payload interfaces) as a form of command and telemetry signaling. In the intended satellite application, the discrete signal interface is used between an MPM and Host System, between an MPM and one or more Payloads, and between a primary and redundant MPM (see Figure 1).
3.2.1.1.4.1 No Text Found Each LVDS Command and Telemetry Discrete signal should be in compliance with the ANSI/TIA/EIA-644 Standard.
3.2.1.1.4.2 No Text Found Each LVDS Command and Telemetry Discrete signal should be driven and received by a 3.3V LVDS driver and receiver.
3.2.1.1.4.3 No Text Found Each LVDS signal should be a balanced differential with the circuit referenced to secondary power ground at the transmitting and receiving ends.
3.2.1.1.4.4 No Text Found Each LVDS discrete command driver should drive a Logic 1 as the default output.
3.2.1.1.4.5 No Text Found Impedance controlled 100 Ohm (+/- 6 Ohms) wire should be used in the MPM harness (in compliance with ANSI/TIA/EIA-644) to match the LVDS receiver 100 Ohm termination resistor.
3.2.1.1.4.6 No Text Found The LVDS Common-Mode Voltage (VCM) should be +1.2V +/- 1V.
3.2.1.1.4.7 No Text Found The LVDS receiver differential input threshold levels should be +/-100 mV with respect to the Common-Mode Voltage (VCM).
3.2.1.1.4.8 No Text Found Upon the application of MPM power, the initial state of each LVDS external interface output signal should be de-asserted.
3.2.1.1.4.9 No Text Found Each LVDS driver and receiver should have inherent cold-spare capabilities (i.e., high impedance or otherwise provide current limiting) such that MPM LVDS device output circuitry stress is prevented when the MPM and the unit it interfaces with via LVDS operate in a Hot-Cold redundancy configuration.
3.2.1.1.4.10 No Text Found Each LVDS discrete command receiver input should default to a logic 1 when not actively driven.
3.2.1.1.5 SpaceWire No Text Found
3.2.1.1.5.1 No Text Found SpaceWire signals should comply with the SpaceWire standard [ECSS-E-ST-50-12C Rev. 1].
3.2.1.1.5.2 No Text Found Each SpaceWire link should support AutoStart and LinkStart [ECSS-ST-50-12C Rev. 1].
3.2.1.1.5.3 No Text Found Each MPM SpaceWire unit connector should be a rectangular, 9-pin, M83513 (e.g., /04) connector.
3.2.1.1.5.4 No Text Found The MPM MPM-to-Host System C&DH SpaceWire interface connector(s) and the MPM MPM-to-Payload C&DH SpaceWire interface connector(s) should comply with the pinout specified in Table 1.
3.2.1.1.6 ETH The MPM ETH Fat pipe (4x lane) interface mates with an interface cable using copper wire to transport the signals.
3.2.1.1.6.1 No Text Found Each ETH interface should comply with IEEE 802.3-2018.
3.2.1.1.6.2 No Text Found Deleted.
3.2.1.1.6.3 No Text Found Each ETH interface should be a full-duplex, 4-lane, channel bonded port, known as a Fat-pipe.
3.2.1.1.6.4 No Text Found Each ETH full duplex lane should support a minimum baud rate of 3.125 Gbps.
3.2.1.1.6.5 No Text Found Each ETH connector should satisfy the attributes specified in Table 2.

3.2.1.2.1.1 No Text Found The MPM should provide twelve (12) payload SpaceWire interfaces, each intended for use by a separate mission payload.
3.2.1.2.1.2 No Text Found The MPM SpaceWire interface should be used to transport all non-discrete digital command and telemetry information between the MPM and each Payload C&DH interface.

3.2.1.2.1.5 No Text Found Each MPM should monitor all discrete telemetry from each Payload C&DH interface.
3.2.1.3 MPM Redundancy Configurations Directly related to architecture, interfaces and MPM responsibilities, there are three redundancy configurations (Hot-Cold, Hot-Warm, and Hot-Hot) that MPMs can support depending upon the fault management warranted by mission requirements.
3.2.1.3.1 MPM Redundancy Configuration Types No Text Found
3.2.1.3.1.1 No Text Found The MPM should be capable of being configured into Hot-Cold, Hot-Warm, or Hot-Hot redundancy configurations in support of mission-level fault management requirements.
3.2.1.3.2 MPM to MPM Redundancy Management Interfaces No Text Found
3.2.1.3.2.1 No Text Found The MPM should have one (1) SpaceWire port (in addition to those for the MPM to Host System interface and the MPM to Payload interfaces) reserved for continuous Active-MPM to Monitor-MPM transfer of information and telemetry needed for the Monitor-MPM to become the new Active-MPM within a period defined by the mission requirements.
3.2.1.3.2.2 No Text Found The MPM should provide a discrete signal interface (i.e., LVDS) input entitled MPM_Active_In_NL.
3.2.1.3.2.3 No Text Found The MPM should provide a discrete signal interface (i.e., LVDS) output entitled MPM_Active_Out_NL.
3.2.1.3.2.4 No Text Found The MPM should provide a discrete signal interface (i.e., LVDS) input entitled Active_Time_Sync_In_NL.
3.2.1.3.2.5 No Text Found The MPM should provide a discrete signal interface (i.e., LVDS) output entitled Active_Time Sync_Out_NL.
3.3 Chassis Requirements No Text Found
3.3.1 Chassis General Requirements No Text Found
3.3.1.1.1.1 No Text Found A single aluminum chassis should house the MPM subassemblies.
3.3.1.1.1.2 No Text Found The MPM chassis walls should have a minimum thickness of 125 mils. Note: MPM chassis wall thickness may vary depending upon the mission required radiation environment.
3.3.1.1.1.3 No Text Found A single-thread MPM chassis envelope should be less than or equal to 15.5” length, 13.3” width, 10.1” height.
3.3.1.1.1.4 No Text Found The MPM should have a weight no greater than 61.5 pounds.
Note: The above weight is for a single-thread MPM with two (2) spare (empty) slots and assumes a mounting placement on the vehicle that provides no shielding that might otherwise reduce the MPM chassis wall thickness and resulting chassis/unit weight. Depending upon the unit placement within the vehicle, the single-thread unit weight could be significantly lower - in the neighborhood of 45 pounds.
3.3.1.1.1.5 No Text Found The MPM center of gravity should be verified to an accuracy of 0.15 inches in the X-Y-Z axis.
3.3.1.1.1.6 No Text Found The MPM mass moment of inertia should be determined to an accuracy of 5 percent.
3.3.1.1.1.7 No Text Found The MPM minimum natural frequency should be greater than 110 Hz.
3.3.1.1.1.8 No Text Found The MPM mounting surface should have a flatness less than or equal to 0.010 in. over the longest dimension.
3.3.1.1.1.9 No Text Found Except for its mounting surface, the MPM chassis external finish should have a black coating with hemispherical emissivity coating greater than or equal to 0.80.
3.3.1.1.1.10 No Text Found The MPM chassis SpaceVPX type should be FLT (flight, or flight equivalent).
3.3.1.1.1.11 No Text Found The MPM chassis should include two separate major portions, one referred to as the Basic-portion and the other as the Switch-portion.
3.3.2 Chassis Internal Requirements No Text Found
3.3.2.1.1.1 No Text Found The MPM chassis should include at least one (1) spare SpaceVPX payload slot in the Basic-portion.
Note: The Basic-portion spare slot is reserved for a cyber (e.g., zero trust architecture) function and/or as a resiliency or unique interface accommodation module; therefore, if such a board is installed into the MPM Basic-portion “spare slot”, the subject requirement remains satisfied.
3.3.2.1.1.2 No Text Found The MPM chassis should include one (1) spare payload slot in the Switch-portion.
Note: The Switch-portion spare slot is reserved for a cyber (e.g., zero trust architecture) function and/or as a resiliency or unique interface accommodation module; therefore, if the such a board is installed into the MPM Basic-portion “spare slot”, the subject requirement remains satisfied.
3.3.2.1.1.3 No Text Found Each MPM internal digital plug-in module and the spare plug-in module should utilize a SpaceVPX 6U module profile per Section 12 of SpaceVPX.
3.3.2.1.1.4 No Text Found The MPM should utilize a backplane for interconnecting internal digital and spare plug-in SpaceVPX modules.
3.3.2.1.1.5 No Text Found All user defined pins on any internal digital plug-in SpaceVPX module and the spare plug-in module in the MPM should be inputs or be configurable to a non-driving state.
Note: All user defined pins that cannot meet this requirement should be fully documented as to output default state, voltage levels, interface type, current requirements, etc.  This will maximize interoperability for future module upgrades inside the MPM.
3.3.2.1.1.6 No Text Found MPM command and data handling between internal digital plug-in SpaceVPX modules (including the spare plug-in module) should utilize SpaceWire control planes per Section 5 of SpaceVPX.
3.3.2.1.1.7 No Text Found MPM low-speed configuration and status between internal digital plug-in SpaceVPX modules including the spare module should utilize either System Management Interfaces on the Utility Plane per Section 3 and 5 of SpaceVPX, or SpaceWire control planes per Section 5 of SpaceVPX.
3.3.2.1.1.8 No Text Found MPM System Management Interfaces on the Utility Plane should support register access through the Direct Access Protocol as defined in Section 3 and 5 of SpaceVPX.
3.3.2.1.1.9 No Text Found MPM System Management Interfaces on the control plane should support RMAP access to DAP addressed registers as defined in the RMAP Protocol for SpaceWire [ECSS-E-ST-50-52C].
3.3.2.1.1.10 No Text Found MPM data connections between internal digital plug-in SpaceVPX modules including the spare module should utilize either Ethernet data plane interfaces per Section 5 of SpaceVPX or SpaceWire control plane interfaces per Section 5 of SpaceVPX.
3.3.2.1.1.11 No Text Found MPM secondary grounds should be internally grounded to the chassis.
3.3.2.1.1.12 No Text Found Impedance between internal grounds or between a connector shell and ground should be less than or equal to 2.5 milli-Ohms.

3.3.2.1.1.14 No Text Found Connectors, compression rings and back-shells should be made of metal with copper under-plating and nickel over-plating on all surfaces.
3.3.2.1.1.15 No Text Found Connector receptacles should have enough spacing so any one connector can be mated or de-mated without requiring the mate or de-mate of a second connector or the removal of a mounted unit from the spacecraft.
3.4 MPM-Host System Interface Requirements This section contains the MPM requirements for the C&DH and power interface signals (see Figure 2) used between the MPM and Host System. The MPM has five categories of electrical interfaces with the Host System: C&DH serial interface (SpaceWire), discrete signaling interface, input power, active analog, and passive analog.
3.4.1 MPM-Host System Interface General Requirements No Text Found
3.4.1.1.1.1 No Text Found The MPM C&DH signals that interface with the Host System should be designed such that an interface short or open would not affect the functionality or performance of other MPM interfaces.
3.4.2 MPM-Host System Interface SpaceWire Interface SpaceWire is used as a point-to-point interface between the Host System and each MPM to exchange commands and telemetry. Host System commands for a payload are sent to the MPM and forwarded by the MPM to the appropriate payload; that is, a SpaceWire router is not hosted by an MPM. Additionally, but not required in this document, the MPM will host cyber oriented capabilities and software that will perform an atypical-command-detection cyber and other cyber related security role. It should also, be noted that additional, emerging cyber capabilities once they mature and are formally documented and justified/mandated - may be included in future versions of MPM specification. A diagram of the MPM to Host System SpaceWire interface is shown in Figure 3.
3.4.2.1 MPM-Host System Interface SpaceWire Interface Characteristics No Text Found
3.4.2.1.1.1 No Text Found The MPM SpaceWire physical layer interfaces used to communicate with the Host System should comply with the [ECSS-E-ST-50-12C, Rev. 1] SpaceWire Standard.
3.4.2.1.1.2 No Text Found The MPM SpaceWire interface used to communicate with the Host System should support data transfer across a copper (wire) medium.
3.4.2.1.1.3 No Text Found Each MPM SpaceWire used to interface with the Host System should be initialized for LinkStart.
3.4.2.1.1.4 No Text Found After initialization, each MPM SpaceWire receive and transmit interface to the Host System should independently support a data rate of 200 Mbps. Each MPM SpaceWire interface should be designed to preclude damage while it is off and being actively driven by its external interfacing equipment (e.g., Host System, or equivalent test interface).
Note: Active voltage of +4.3V.
3.4.2.1.1.5 No Text Found The MPM should not host a SpaceWire Switch to transfer information (e.g., commands, data) to or from the Host System.
Note 1: The MPM will receive, process, and, when necessary, individually forward commands and data to the Host System.  It is envisioned that the MPM will host a cyber-related capability to monitor all commands between the Host System and MPM, between MPM and Payload(s), and between MPMs; and a  Switch would circumvent that capability.   
3.4.2.2 MPM-Host System Interface SpaceWire Quantity and Names No Text Found
3.4.2.2.1.1 No Text Found The MPM should provide two (2) SpaceWire unit connectors as part of its Host System interface.
Note: One will be dedicated to interface with the A-side of a Host System and the other dedicated to interface with a B-side of the Host System.
3.4.2.2.1.2 No Text Found The MPM SpaceWire port used to communicate with the A-side of the Host System should be identified as SpW_A.
3.4.2.2.1.3 No Text Found The MPM SpaceWire port used to communicate with the B-side of the Host System should be identified as SpW_B.
3.4.2.3 MPM-Host System Interface SpaceWire Connector No Text Found
3.4.2.3.1.1 No Text Found Each MPM MPM-to-Host System SpaceWire unit connector should be a rectangular, 9-pin, M83513 (e.g., /04) connector.
3.4.2.4 MPM-Host System Interface SpaceWire Connector Pinout No Text Found
3.4.2.4.1.1 No Text Found Each MPM-to-Host System SpaceWire unit connector should have the pinout specified in Table 1.

3.4.3.5 MPM Input (from Host System) Discrete Signal Characteristics No Text Found
3.4.3.5.1 MPM_Select_NL No Text Found
3.4.3.5.1.1 No Text Found The MPM should interpret its MPM_Select_NL discrete command input as asserted (selected) when the signal is a logic 0.
3.4.3.5.1.2 No Text Found While the MPM_Select_NLA signal is asserted, the MPM should enable SpaceWire communication over SpaceWire port A (i.e., A-side of the Host System).
3.4.3.5.1.3 No Text Found While the MPM_Select_NLA signal is de-asserted, the MPM should disable SpaceWire communication over SpaceWire port A.
3.4.3.5.1.4 No Text Found While the MPM_Select_NLB signal is asserted, the MPM should enable SpaceWire communication over SpaceWire port B (i.e., B-side of the Host System).
3.4.3.5.1.5 No Text Found While the MPM_Select_NLB signal is de-asserted, the MPM should disable SpaceWire communication over SpaceWire port B.
3.4.3.5.2 MPM_Hard_Reset_NL No Text Found
3.4.3.5.2.1 No Text Found The MPM should interpret its MPM_Hard_Reset_NL discrete command input as asserted (selected) when the signal is a logic 0 for 10 milliseconds (+/- 10%) and subsequently transitions to logic 1 for at least 10 milliseconds.
3.4.3.5.2.2 No Text Found The MPM should interpret its MPM_Hard_Reset_NL discrete command input as de-asserted (de-selected) when the signal is a logic 1.
3.4.3.5.2.3 No Text Found When the MPM_Hard_Reset_NL discrete command input is asserted (selected), the MPM should reset its internal cards to initial states and emulate a power on reset, without the need to interrupt the main power input to the MPM.
3.4.3.5.2.4 No Text Found Upon detection of a valid MPM_Hard_Reset_NL, the MPM processor should reset its memory pointer to the first address of the Startup ROM, reset all timers, registers, processors, and interfaces.
3.4.3.5.2.5 No Text Found After processing an MPM_Hard_Reset_NL, the MPM should enter the Idle Mode.
3.4.3.5.3 MPM_Soft_Reset_NL No Text Found
3.4.3.5.3.1 No Text Found When the MPM_Soft_Reset_NL C&DH interface signal is driven to logic 0 for 10 milliseconds (+/- 10%) and subsequently transitions to logic 1 for at least 10 milliseconds, the MPM should reload its operating system and flight software.
3.4.3.5.3.2 No Text Found As part of the processing a soft reset interrupt, the MPM should initialize its SpaceWire interfaces with LinkStart enabled.
3.4.3.5.3.3 No Text Found After processing an MPM_Soft_Reset_NL the MPM should enter the Idle Mode.
3.4.3.5.4 HS_Time_Sync_NL Synchronizing MPM time to Host System time is a two-step process. Typically, the Host System would use SpaceWire to send the MPM the value of an approaching time for subsequent loading into an MPM timer; and, once that exact time is reached the Host System would immediately assert its HS_Time_Sync_NL discrete, which interfaces with the MPM. When the MPM edge detects the assertion of the HS_Time_Sync_NL signal, it would load the predefined time value into a timekeeping register for the Host System Domain Time Counter. This process is repeated periodically to ensure that Host System time and MPM time are synchronized.
3.4.3.5.4.1 No Text Found The MPM should use the falling edge (logic 1 to logic 0 transition) of the HS_Time_Sync_NL signal to serve as the time of reference instance for synchronization.
3.4.3.6 MPM Output (to HS-Host System Subsystem) Discrete Signal Characteristics No Text Found
3.4.3.6.1 MPM_Ready_NL This signal would be used by the MPM to indicate when it has powered up successfully and is ready for operation.
3.4.3.6.1.1 No Text Found Assertion of the MPM_Ready_NL discrete output should be logic 0.
3.4.3.6.1.2 No Text Found The MPM should assert its MPM_Ready_NL discrete output after the following conditions have been met:

 

Sub-¶

 

a.

The MPM has successfully booted up

b.

MPM has passed post-boot diagnostic tests

c.

Local version of flight software ready for use

d.

SpaceWire services are ready for operations


3.4.3.6.1.3 No Text Found MPM_Ready_NL should be logic 1 when the MPM SpaceWire is not ready for operations or reset (Hard Reset or Soft Reset) occurs.
3.4.3.6.2 MPM_Fault No Text Found
3.4.3.6.2.1 No Text Found Assertion of the MPM_Fault discrete output should be logic 1.
3.4.3.6.2.2 No Text Found The MPM_Fault discrete output should be asserted when it detects that any of the following conditions occur:

Sub-¶

 

a.

SpaceWire communications with the Host System are not operational

b.

MPM processor watchdog timer timeout

c.

Detection of an uncorrectable memory error within the Basic-portion of the MPM

Note: An MPM RIO Switch_Fault is reported to the Host System via SpaceWire telemetry.

3.4.3.6.2.3 No Text Found The MPM_Fault status should be clearable by SpaceWire command from the Host System. Note: There are multiple options for attempting to clear unit faults (e.g., unit reset [hard or soft], or command) and the method used may depend upon fault type.
3.4.3.6.2.4 No Text Found The MPM should drive the MPM_Fault Telemetry Discrete Command to Logic 0 when there are no MPM faults to report to the Host System.
3.4.3.6.3 Aux_Time_Sync_NL The Aux_Time_Sync_NL signal is a discrete output from the MPM to the Host System and it is used to synchronize Host Systems time to a time provided by the MPM. Typically, the MPM would provide the Host System with an approaching time via SpaceWire. Subsequently, when the exact time occurs within the MPM, based on its Aux Time Clock, it would assert its Aux_Time_Sync_NL. The Host System would then use the edge of that signal to load the time value into its appropriate time keeping register.
3.4.3.6.3.1 No Text Found The MPM should use the falling edge of the Aux_Time_Sync_NL signal to serve as the time of reference instance for synchronization.
3.4.3.6.3.2 No Text Found The assertion of Aux_Time_Sync_NL should have an accuracy of 25 ns or less relative to the falling edge of the clock used to maintain time within the MPM.
3.4.3.6.3.3 No Text Found The MPM should de-assert its Aux_Time_Sync_NL at least 100 microseconds after assertion.
3.4.4 MPM-Host System Interface Power Interface To accommodate the current multiple levels of supplier intra-satellite prime power voltage ranges, the MPM input power will accommodate a single wide-voltage-range type, which will have an input operating voltage range of 24 VDC to 105 VDC maximum. Additionally, to accommodate low power conditions such as safe-Mode, the Basic-portion and Switch-portion of the MPM will have separate input power connectors, each individually controlled by the Host System.
3.4.4.1 MPM Power Interface No Text Found
3.4.4.1.1 MPM Power Interface, Type 1 (24-105V) No Text Found
3.4.4.1.1.1 No Text Found An MPM Type 1 should satisfy its specified performance requirements operating over an input voltage range between 24 VDC and 105 VDC.
3.4.4.1.1.2 No Text Found Each MPM Type 1 power converter should have a DC source impedance of 20 m to 100 m.
3.4.4.1.1.3 No Text Found The MPM Basic-portion with a Type 1 power interface should consume no more than 55 W maximum power.
Note: Includes accommodation for the space plug-in module.
3.4.4.1.1.4 No Text Found The MPM Switch-portion with a Type 1 power interface should consume no more than 115 W maximum power.
Note: Includes accommodation for the space plug-in module.
3.4.4.1.1.5 No Text Found Each MPM Type 1 power converter should meet a step inrush maximum of 5x maximum input current within 100 s and drop to 2.5x within 10 ms.
3.4.4.1.1.6 No Text Found Each MPM Type 1 power converter should survive the application of input voltage ranging from 0 V to 115 V with no damage.
3.4.4.1.1.7 No Text Found Each MPM Type 1 power converter should provide overcurrent limiting at 250% within 100 ms.
Note: the overcurrent set point must be greater than 200% to provide fuse blow margin in fuse Host System application.
3.4.4.1.1.8 No Text Found Each MPM Type 1 power converter should provide independent overvoltage protection on the primary power input at input voltages in excess of 115 V.
3.4.4.1.1.9 No Text Found Each MPM Type 1 power converter should operate from an input voltage ranging from 24 VDC to 105 VDC.
3.4.4.1.1.10 No Text Found Each MPM Type 1 power converter should meet a step inrush maximum of 5x maximum input current within 100 s and drop to 2.5x within 10ms.
3.4.4.1.1.11 No Text Found Each MPM Type 1 power converter should survive the application of input voltage ranging from 0 V to 115 V indefinitely with no damage.
3.4.4.1.1.12 No Text Found Each MPM Type 1 power converter that would provide power to MPM modules should provide overcurrent limiting at 200% within 100 ms.
3.4.4.1.1.13 No Text Found Each MPM Type 1 power converter that would provide power to MPM modules should provide independent overvoltage limiting at 120% of nominal within 1 ms.
3.4.4.2 MPM Power Interface Connector No Text Found
3.4.4.2.1.1 No Text Found The primary power unit connector for the Basic-portion of each MPM should be a 37-pin micro-D subminiature (Part number: M24308/24-152).
3.4.4.2.1.2 No Text Found The primary power unit connector for the Switch-portion of each MPM should be a 37-pin micro-D subminiature (Part number: M24308/24-152).
3.4.4.3 MPM Basic-portion Power Interface Connector Pinout No Text Found

3.4.5 MPM-Host System Interface Passive Analog Interface No Text Found
3.4.5.1 Passive Analog (Resistive) Interface Characteristics Each MPM provides thermal telemetry to the Host System for purposes of MPM internal temperature diagnostics.

The return side of each thermistor is ganged together, isolated from all grounds and continues to the Host System as shown for reference only in Figure 5. The thermistors may be S-311-P18-05 or equivalent (5k Ohm at nominal).
3.4.5.1.1.1 No Text Found Each MPM passive analog signal should be a single-ended signal, with a return.
3.4.5.1.1.2 No Text Found Each MPM passive analog signal should be isolated from chassis by > 1 Mega Ohm.
3.4.5.1.1.3 No Text Found The thermistor should be an S-311-P-18, dash number 5 (5k ohms at nominal) or equivalent.
3.4.5.2 Passive Analog (Resistive) Signal Quantity and Names No Text Found
3.4.5.2.1.1 No Text Found Each MPM should provide four cross-strapped Passive Analog (Resistive) telemetry interfaces for Host System external monitoring of high-power consumption area within the MPM.
3.4.5.2.1.2 No Text Found There should be at least one thermal sensor in the Basic-portion of the MPM.
Note: Thermal sensors should be placed in close proximity to the hottest area of each portion of the MPM.
3.4.5.2.1.3 No Text Found There should be at least one thermal sensor in the Switch-portion of the MPM.
Note: Thermal sensors should be placed in close proximity to the hottest area of each portion of the MPM.
3.4.5.3 Passive Analog (Resistive) Signal Connector No Text Found

3.4.5.3.1.2 No Text Found Each MPM Passive Analog signal provided to the Host System should be single-ended, with a return in the harness.
3.4.5.3.1.3 No Text Found Each portion (Basic, Switch) of the MPM should use a dedicated connector for its Passive Analog signals.

3.5 MPM Payload-Interface Requirements The MPM has three categories of C&DH electrical interfaces with each payload: SpaceWire (SpW), discrete signals, and Ethernet (ETH): see Figure 6.
3.5.1 MPM Payload-Interface General Requirements No Text Found
3.5.1.1.1.1 No Text Found The MPM payload interfaces should be designed such that an external interface short or open should not affect the functionality of other MPM interfaces.
3.5.2 MPM Payload-Interface SpaceWire Interface SpaceWire is used as a point-to-point serial command and telemetry interface between the MPM and each Payload.
3.5.2.1.1.1 No Text Found The MPM payload physical layer interfaces should comply with the [ECSS-E-ST-50-12C, Rev. 1] SpaceWire Standard.
3.5.2.1.1.2 No Text Found After initialization, each MPM to Payload SpaceWire receive and transmit interface should independently support a data rate of 200 Mbps.
3.5.2.1.1.3 No Text Found Each MPM to Payload SpaceWire interface should be designed to preclude damage while it is off and being actively driven by Payload.
Note: Active voltage of 4.3V.
3.5.2.1.1.4 No Text Found Deleted.
3.5.2.2 MPM Payload-Interface SpaceWire Quantity and Names No Text Found
3.5.2.2.1.1 No Text Found The MPM payload-interface should provide 12 SpaceWire ports. Note: See Figure 1.
3.5.2.3 MPM Payload-Interface SpaceWire Connector No Text Found
3.5.2.3.1.1 No Text Found Each MPM payload-interface SpaceWire unit connector should be a rectangular, 9-pin, M83513 (e.g., /04) connector.
3.5.2.4 MPM Payload-Interface SpaceWire Connector Pinout No Text Found
3.5.2.4.1.1 No Text Found Each MPM payload-interface SpaceWire unit connector should have the pinout specified in Table 1.
3.5.3 MPM Payload-Interface Discrete Signal Interface All MPM-to-Payload Discrete Signals are defined as LVDS signals. A simplified diagram of the discrete signal interface between the MPM and the Payloads is shown in Figure 7.
3.5.3.1 MPM Payload-Interface Output Discrete Signal Quantity and Names No Text Found
3.5.3.1.1.1 No Text Found For each of its 12 payload interfaces, the MPM should provide four Discrete Signal outputs.
3.5.3.1.1.2 No Text Found Each of the 12 MPM to payload Discrete Signals should be identified as follows:

 

Sub-¶

Signal Name

(“N” used to simplify iterations 1-12)

[MPM & Payload signal base names are identical]

{payload “1” example: PL_IF_Port_Select_NL_01}

a.

PL_IF_Port_Select_NL “N”

b.

PL_Hard_Reset_NL “N”

c.

PL_Soft_Reset_NL “N”

d.

PL_Time_Sync_NL “N”

 

3.5.3.2 MPM Payload-Interface Input Discrete Signal Quantity and Names No Text Found
3.5.3.2.1.1 No Text Found The MPM should provide three Discrete Signal inputs per payload from a total of 12 payloads.
3.5.3.2.1.2 No Text Found One of the three MPM input Discrete Signals per payload should be reserved for general purpose use.
Note: If a payload is used to provide an alternate time sync signal, for example, the MPM input designated for general purpose use would be used to receive that time sync signal.

3.5.3.3 MPM Payload-Interface Discrete Signal Connector No Text Found
3.5.3.3.1.1 No Text Found The MPM Discrete Signal unit connector part number should be M24308/23-165 or equivalent.
3.5.3.4 MPM Payload-Interface Output and Input Discrete Signal Pinout No Text Found
3.5.3.4.1.1 No Text Found The MPM Discrete Signals interfacing with the Payloads should conform to the pinout specified in Appendix B Table 16.
3.5.3.5 MPM Payload-Interface Output Discrete Signal Characteristics No Text Found
3.5.3.5.1 PL_IF_Port_Select_NL No Text Found
3.5.3.5.1.1 No Text Found To enable a specific payload C&DH interface port (i.e., 1-12) to actively communicate with the MPM, the MPM should apply a logic 0 to its PL_IF_Port_Select_NL output signal.
3.5.3.5.1.2 No Text Found To disable a specific payload C&DH interface port (i.e., 1-12) from actively communicating with it, the MPM should apply a logic 1 to its respective PL_IF_Port_Select_NL output signal.
3.5.3.5.2 PL_Hard_Reset_NL No Text Found
3.5.3.5.2.1 No Text Found To reset a specific payloads C&DH interface (i.e., 1-12), the MPM should set the respective payloads PL_Hard_Reset_NL signal to logic 0 for at least 10 ms before returning that signal to a logic 1.
3.5.3.5.3 PL_Soft_Reset_NL No Text Found
3.5.3.5.3.1 No Text Found For an MPM to cause a specific payload C&DH interface (i.e., 1-12) to abort execution of its operating system, and enter into the Standby State, without removing power (primary or secondary) or resetting the payloads hardware functions, the MPM should apply a logic 0 to the respective payloads PL_Soft_Reset_NL discrete for at least 10 ms and then apply a logic 1.
3.5.3.5.4 PL_Time_Sync_NL The PL_Time_Sync_NL signal is a discrete output to payloads to synchronize their internal time to a common time domain. The MPM provides a payload time management function. The source of time synchronization may be the Host System or a payload. Consequently, the PL_Time_Sync_NL signal timing is derived from either the HS_Time_Sync_NL signal from the Host System or from the Alt Source Time Sync signal from a payload.
3.5.3.5.4.1 No Text Found To notify a specific payload (i.e., 1-12) when a predefined time occurs, the MPM should apply a logic 0 pulse of 100 s to the respective payloads PL_Time_Sync_NL output.
3.5.3.5.4.2 No Text Found The MPM should use the falling edge of the PL_Time_Sync_NL signal to serve as the time of reference instance for synchronization.
3.5.3.5.4.3 No Text Found The assertion of MPM PL_Time_Sync_NL should have an accuracy of 25 ns or less relative to the falling edge of the clock used to maintain time within the MPM.
3.5.3.6 MPM Input (from Payloads) Discrete Signal Characteristics No Text Found
3.5.3.6.1 PL_Ready_NL The PL_Ready_NL discrete represents an input to the MPM from the payload domain. The discrete would become a logic 0 during a payload power-on or Hard Reset event and would return to a logic 1 once the payload is ready to conduct SpaceWire transactions with the MPM.
3.5.3.6.1.1 No Text Found The MPM should individually recognize each PL_Ready_NL input as valid after the input has been a logic 0 for 10 s.
3.5.3.6.1.2 No Text Found The MPM should not initiate command and data handling SpaceWire transactions with a Payload until that payload has asserted a valid PL_Ready_NL input to the MPM.
3.5.3.6.2 PL_Fault The PL_Fault discrete represents an input to the MPM from the Payload domain. After a payload is ready its PL_Fault discrete would only become a logic 1 if the payload is reporting a fault or it is no longer operational (e.g., power was removed).
3.5.3.6.2.1 No Text Found The MPM should individually recognize each PL_Fault input as valid after the input has been a logic 1 for 10 s.
3.5.3.6.2.2 No Text Found The state of each PL_Fault input should be registered and accessible by the MPM processor.
3.5.3.6.2.3 No Text Found A valid PL_Fault logic 1 should be capable of interrupting the MPM processor.
3.5.3.6.3 Alt_Source_Time_Sync This payload sourced signal is not commonly provided by payloads; consequently, a discrete signal is not directly specified for this function. Instead, this signal would use the PL General Purpose_NL signal, which may be used for this or another unique payload to MPM discrete signaling.
The MPM PL_Time_Sync_NL signal is a discrete output to payloads to synchronize their internal time to a common time domain. While the MPM provides a Payload time management function, its original source of time is either the Host System or a payload. Consequently, the MPM PL_Time_Sync_NL signal timing is derived from either the HS_Time_Sync_NL signal from the Host System or the Alt_Source_Time_Sync signal from a payload.
3.5.3.6.3.1 No Text Found When a payload provides an Alt_Source_Time_Sync across its PL_General_Purpose_NL discrete signal, the MPM should interpret the assertion of that signal as a transition from a logic 1 state to transition logic 0 state.
3.5.3.6.3.2 No Text Found When used as an Alt_Source_Time_Sync signal, the MPM should use the falling edge (logic 1 to logic 0 transition) of the PL_General_Purpose_NL signal to load a previously provided payload provided time value into Alt_Source_Time_Sync register.
3.5.3.6.3.3 No Text Found The Alt_Source_Time_Sync register should be composed of a 54-bit re-loadable register.
3.5.3.6.3.4 No Text Found The MPM Alt_Source_Time_Sync register clock should use a clock frequency of 40.92 MHz.
3.5.3.6.3.5 No Text Found The MPM should be able to read the PL_Time_clock register without interrupting the PL Time_clock operation.
3.5.3.6.4 PL_General_Purpose_NL The PL_General_Purpose_NL signal is reserved for use in the event that there is a need for a payload to provide a unique signal to the MPM. Consequently, the PL_General_Purpose_NL input signal can be selected by the MPM to serve as an MPM processor interrupt or it can be used by a single payload to provide a time sync input pulse from that payload. For example, if a payload includes a time source useful to the system for managing the payloads, that payload could provide an auxiliary or primary time sync pulse to the MPM using the PL_General_Purpose_NL input. In that case, the PL_General_Purpose_NL input would serve as an Alt_Source_Time_Sync signal.
3.5.3.6.4.1 No Text Found The state of each PL_General_Purpose_NL discrete signal should be registered and accessible by the MPM processor.
3.5.3.6.4.2 No Text Found The MPM should be able to select whether the PL_General_Purpose_NL input would set an MPM processor interrupt or be used to reload the Auxiliary_Payload_Time_Domain_Source_Time_Sync register.
3.5.3.6.4.3 No Text Found The MPM should interpret an event indication on each PL_General_Purpose_NL discrete signal as a transition from a logic 1 state to the logic 0 state.
3.5.3.6.4.4 No Text Found The MPM should be able to selectively route any one of the PL_General_Purpose_NL discrete signals for purposes of triggering the reload of an Alt_Source_Time_Sync counter.
3.5.3.6.4.5 No Text Found When the PL_General_Purpose_NL signal is used to drive an MPM processor interrupt, a transition from logic 1 to 0 should set the MPM interrupt.
3.5.3.6.4.6 No Text Found When the PL_General_Purpose_NL signal is used to reload the Auxiliary_Payload_Time_Domain_Register, a transition from logic 1 to 0 should load the register.
3.5.4 MPM Switch Payload-Interface The MPM Switch is responsible for routing payload-to-payload data transfers over a Ethernet network. Any data encryption requirements are the responsibility of the payloads.
3.5.4.1 ETH Characteristics No Text Found
3.5.4.1.1.1 No Text Found The MPM Switch-portion should support ETH frame switching capabilities.
3.5.4.1.1.2 No Text Found The transmit side of the Ethernet interfaces should comply with Section 54.6.3 of [IEEE 2018].
3.5.4.1.1.3 No Text Found The receive side of the Ethernet interfaces should comply with Section 54.6.4 [IEEE 2018].
3.5.4.1.1.4 No Text Found A free running pseudo-random bit-sequence per chapter 5.8 of [ITU-T-T O.150 with corrigendum May 2002] should be used for the testing of bit error rate compliance.
3.5.4.1.1.5 No Text Found The MPM should provide an independent Bit Error Rate (BER) built in test (BIT) for each SERDES interface lane.
3.5.4.1.1.6 No Text Found Each SERDES lane should support PRBS-31 in-situ BER testing.
3.5.4.1.1.7 No Text Found Each MPM ETH interface should be designed to preclude damage while it is off and being actively driven by Payload.
Note: Active voltage of +/- 0.800 mV.
3.5.4.1.1.8 No Text Found The MPM Switch-portion should be configurable by the Basic-portion via command.
3.5.4.1.1.9 No Text Found The MPM should support configuring SERDES parametric via command.
3.5.4.2 ETH Quantity No Text Found
3.5.4.2.1.1 No Text Found Each MPM should provide twelve (12) non-redundant ETH Fat-Pipe ports, at least one for each (up to 12) Payload.
3.5.4.2.1.2 No Text Found Each ETH Fat-Pipe port should have its own connector.
3.5.4.2.1.3 No Text Found The last two digits of each ETH connector number should correspond to the ETH port number (e.g., ETH port 01 connector would be labeled J101 and port 12 would be labeled J112).
3.5.4.3 ETH Connector No Text Found
3.5.4.3.1.1 No Text Found Each MPM ETH unit connector part number should satisfy the connector attributes specified in Table 2.
3.5.4.4 ETH Pinout No Text Found
3.5.4.4.1.1 No Text Found Each MPM ETH unit connector should have the pinout specified in Table 3.
3.6 MPM to MPM Interface Requirements The MPM to MPM interface is intended to be used for managing MPM redundancy in a Hot-Hot configuration. A simplified diagram of the MPM to MPM interface is shown in Figure 9.
3.6.1 MPM to MPM SpaceWire Interface When the MPMs are configured to support a Hot-Hot redundancy configuration, there is a need for MPM A and MPM B to communicate with each other to ensure the monitor MPM receives the latest telemetry information from the currently active MPM. SpaceWire is used as the means for the active MPM to provide that information to the monitor MPM, thereby enabling the monitor MPM (e.g., MPM B), in the event of a failure of the currently active MPM (e.g., MPM A), to rapidly take over the role as the new active MPM. Each MPM has a discrete signal output to an input on the other MPM indicating whether the MPM is in the Active Mode.
3.6.1.1 MPM to MPM SpaceWire Interface Characteristics No Text Found
3.6.1.1.1.1 No Text Found In support of the Hot-Hot configuration, the MPM A SpW_Hot port should interface with the MPM B SpW_Hot port.
3.6.1.1.1.2 No Text Found When configured in a Hot-Hot redundancy configuration, the Active MPM Hot-Hot SpareWire interface should be initialized for AutoStart.
3.6.1.1.1.3 No Text Found When configured in a Hot-Hot redundancy configuration, the Monitor MPM Hot-Hot SpareWire interface should be initialized for LinkStart.
3.6.1.1.1.4 No Text Found In the Hot-Hot configuration, after initialization, each MPM SpaceWire receive and transmit interface to the other MPM should independently support a maximum data rate of 200 Mbps.
3.6.1.2 MPM to MPM SpaceWire Quantity and Names No Text Found
3.6.1.2.1.1 No Text Found Each MPM should provide a SpaceWire port dedicated for use only when the MPMs are configured for a Hot-Hot configuration.
3.6.1.2.1.2 No Text Found In support of the Hot-Hot configurations, the SpaceWire port used to communicate with the other MPM should be identified as SpW_Hot.
3.6.1.3 MPM to MPM SpaceWire Connector No Text Found
3.6.1.3.1.1 No Text Found The MPM SpaceWire unit connector part number should be a rectangular, 9-pin, M83513 (e.g., /04 or /19) connector.
3.6.1.4 MPM to MPM SpaceWire Pinout No Text Found
3.6.1.4.1.1 No Text Found The MPM-to-MPM SpaceWire unit connector should have the pinout specified in Table 1.
3.6.2 MPM to MPM Discrete Signals No Text Found
3.6.2.1 MPM to MPM Discrete Signal (Output) Interface Characteristics No Text Found
3.6.2.1.1.1 No Text Found When an MPM is commanded by the Host System to enter into Monitor Mode, it should set the MPM_Active_Out_NL discrete to logic 1.
3.6.2.1.1.2 No Text Found When an MPM is commanded by the Host System to enter into Active Mode, it should set the MPM_Active_Out_NL discrete to logic 0.
3.6.2.1.1.3 No Text Found When an MPM in the Active Mode detects that its watchdog timer timed-out or the MPM detects a multi-bit memory error it should set the MPM_Active_Out_NL discrete to logic 1.
3.6.2.1.1.4 No Text Found When an MPM is in the Monitor Mode and it detects that the other MPM has set its MPM_Active_Out_NL discrete to logic 1, the MPM that is currently in Monitor Mode should transition to Active Mode and perform the Active Mode function (including assuming payload interface management control) within 500 milliseconds, unless otherwise specified by the mission requirements.
3.6.2.1.1.5 No Text Found When in the Hot-Hot configuration, to notify the Monitor MPM when a predefined time (transported via MPM to MPM SpareWire interface) occurs, the Active MPM should assert its Active_Time_Sync_Out_NL discrete with a logic 0 for at least 100 microseconds then de-assert it with a logic 1.
3.6.2.1.1.6 No Text Found The falling edge (logic 1 to 0 transition) of the Active MPMs Active_Time_Sync_Out_NL should occur within 25 ns of the predefined time.

3.7 MPM Internal Basic/Switch Interface Requirements The MPM internal Switch/Basic interface enables the Basic-portion and Switch-portion of the MPM to communicate with each other within the MPM.
It is likely that there will be MPM use-cases where the MPM Switch-portion would include signaling routed between payloads that have a higher-level of security than those within the Basic-portion. Based on that scenario, National Security (NSA) representatives strongly recommended that steps be taken to isolate signaling occurring between the Switch-portion and the Basic-portion. The isolation would be accomplished by double buffering signals that go between the Switch-portion and Basic-portions.
3.7.1 Basic/Switch Bidirectional Serial-Communication Interface No Text Found
3.7.1.1.1.1 No Text Found The MPM Basic-portion and Switch-portion should each provide a single shared Spacewire port reserved for communication between each portion.
3.7.1.1.1.2 No Text Found The Spacewire signaling between the Basic-portion and the Switch-portion should be double-clocked.
Note: This signaling would be used only to transport Switch commands, Switch controls, and Switch status signaling between the Basic-portion and the Switch-portion of the MPM: it would not be used to transport any information being routed through a Switch.
3.7.1.1.1.3 No Text Found The implementation of the Spacewire signaling (i.e., signal double clocking within MPM portions) should be approved by the NSA.
3.7.1.1.1.4 No Text Found The routing of the SpaceWire wiring between the Basic- and Switch-portions should be approved by the NSA.
3.7.2 Basic-portion to Switch-portion Discrete Signaling Interface No Text Found
3.7.2.1.1.1 No Text Found Each discrete signal from the Basic-portion to the Switch-portion should be double clocked (two latching buffers in a series configuration).
3.7.2.1.1.2 No Text Found The MPM Basic to Switch interface should include the following four (4) discrete LVDS signals:

 

Sub-¶

Signal Name

a.

Switch-portion_Processor_Hard_Reset_NL

b.

Switch-portion_Processor_Soft_Reset_NL

c.

Switch_Device_Reset_NL

d.

Basic-portion_Fault_NL

 

3.7.2.1.1.3 No Text Found The implementation of the LVDS signaling (e.g., double clocking within portions) should be approved by the NSA.
3.7.2.1.1.4 No Text Found The routing of the LVDS wiring between the Basic- and Switch-portions should be approved by the NSA.
3.7.2.1.1.5 No Text Found The Basic-portion assertion (logic 0) of the Switch-portion_Processor_Hard_Reset_NL interface signal for a minimum duration equivalent to 255 periods of the Switch processor clock followed by de-assertion should cause the Switch-portion processor to perform a hard-reset.
Note: The 255 cycles of logic “0” assertion are needed to reset Switch circuitry and allow the Switch phase-lock-loop to achieve lock.
3.7.2.1.1.6 No Text Found The assertion of the- Switch-portion_Hard_Reset_NL signal should cause the Switch-portion processor to vector to its Hard Reset Starting Address.
Note: The Hard Reset Starting Address value would be defined by specification for the processor implemented within the Switch-portion.
3.7.2.1.1.7 No Text Found The Basic-portion assertion (logic 0) of the Switch-portion_Processor_Soft_Reset_NL interface signal for the equivalent of at least two (2) Switch processor clock cycles followed by de-assertion should cause the Switch-portions processor to perform a soft-reset.
3.7.2.1.1.8 No Text Found The Basic-portion assertion (logic 0) of the Switch_Device_Reset_NL interface signal for a minimum duration of 10 milli-seconds before de-assertion should cause the Switch-device to perform a reset.
3.7.2.1.1.9 No Text Found When power is applied, the Basic-portions Basic-portion_Fault_NL signal should initialize to logic 1.
3.7.2.1.1.10 No Text Found When the Basic-portion Processor detects a critical processing fault (e.g., multi-bit error, software time-out/fault) its Basic-portion_Fault_NL at the Basic/Switch interface should be logic 0.
3.7.3 Switch-portion to Basic-portion Discrete Signaling Interface No Text Found
3.7.3.1.1.1 No Text Found Each discrete signal from the Switch-portion to the Basic-portion should be double clocked (two latched buffers in a series configuration).
3.7.3.1.1.2 No Text Found The MPM Switch to Basic interface should include the following five (5) discrete LVDS signals:

Signal Name

a.

Switch_ Portion_ON_NL

b.

Switch_Ready_NL

c.

d.

e.

3.7.3.1.1.3 No Text Found The implementation of the LVDS signaling (e.g., signal double clocking within portions) should be approved by the NSA.
3.7.3.1.1.4 No Text Found The routing of the LVDS wiring between the Basic- and Switch-portions should be approved by the NSA.
3.7.3.2 Switch_ Portion_ON_NL No Text Found
3.7.3.2.1.1 No Text Found During initial application of primary input power to the Switch-portion, the Switch-portion to Basic-portion interface signal entitled Switch_ Portion_ON_NL should be a logic 1.
3.7.3.2.1.2 No Text Found When the Switch-portion Switch successfully completes its initialization and the Processor completes its software initialization, the Switch_ Portion_ON_NL signal should be logic 0.
Note: Once the Switch-portion has completed its hardware and software initialization, it would be ready for its application initialization.  Application information transfers would occur over the SpaceWire interface between the Basic- and Switch-portions.  Those transactions would likely need to be reviewed by the NSA.
3.7.3.3 Switch_Ready_NL No Text Found
3.7.3.3.1.1 No Text Found During initial application of primary input power to the Switch-portion, the Switch-portion to Basic-portion interface signal entitled Switch_Ready_NL should be a logic 1.
3.7.3.3.1.2 No Text Found After the Switch-portion Switch has successfully completed its hardware initialization, the Switch_Ready_NL signal should be logic 0.
3.7.3.4 Processor_Ready_NL
3.7.3.4.1.1 No Text Found During initial application of primary input power to the Switch-portion, the Switch-portion to Basic-portion interface signal entitled Processor_Ready_NL should be a logic 1.
3.7.3.4.1.2 No Text Found After the Switch-portion Processor has successfully completed its hardware initialization, the Processor_Ready_NL signal should be logic 0.
3.7.3.5 Switch_Fault No Text Found
3.7.3.5.1.1 No Text Found After the Switch-portion Switch has successfully completed hardware initialization, and the Switch has no faults, the Switch_Fault signal should be logic 0.
3.7.3.5.1.2 No Text Found When the Switch-portion Switch detects a fault, the Switch_Fault signal should be logic 1.
3.7.3.6 Processor_Fault No Text Found
3.7.3.6.1.1 No Text Found After the Switch-portion Processor has successfully completed its hardware initialization, and the Processor has no faults, the Processor_Fault signal should be logic 0.
3.7.3.6.1.2 No Text Found When the Switch-portion Processor detects a fault condition that is not autonomously correctable, it should set the Processor_Fault to logic 1 within 100 micro-seconds.
3.8 MPM States and Modes No Text Found
3.8.1 Power On and Off No Text Found
3.8.1.1.1.1 No Text Found The MPM Basic-portion and Switch-portion should have independent power inputs.
Note: The purpose of using independent power inputs is to enable the MPM to operate in a low power Mode when necessary (i.e., when the satellite is in a low power Mode [e.g., safe Mode]).
3.8.1.1.1.2 No Text Found The Switch-portion should not be ON when the Basic-portion is OFF.
3.8.1.1.1.3 No Text Found Upon initial application of power to the MPM Basic-portion, it should enter Standby State.
3.8.1.1.1.4 No Text Found After initial application of power, the MPM should enter Idle Mode.
3.8.1.1.1.5 No Text Found When power is applied to the Basic-portion and the Switch-portion, the MPM should enter Operational State.
3.8.2 States and Modes The diagram in Figure 10 depicts valid MPM States and Modes. While the MPM flight software may include autonomous actions to transition from one Mode to another, functional requirements for those autonomous actions are not specified in this equipment specification. Note that there is no valid MPM State or Mode where the MPM Switch-portion is ON and the MPM Basic-portion is OFF.
3.8.2.1 States No Text Found
3.8.2.1.1.1 No Text Found An MPM should be in a Standby State when its Basic-portion is powered on and its Switch-portion is off.
Note: See  Figure 10 (MPM States and Modes).
3.8.2.1.1.2 No Text Found An MPM should be in an Operational State when its Basic-portion and Switch-portion have powered applied to them.
Note: See  Figure 10 (MPM States and Modes).
3.8.2.2 Modes No Text Found
3.8.2.2.1.1 No Text Found The MPM should enter into a valid Mode when commanded via its Host System interface (i.e., SpaceWire) to enter that Mode.
Note: See Figure 10 (MPM States and Modes).
3.8.2.2.1.2 No Text Found When commanded via its Host System interface (i.e., SpaceWire) to reset the Switch-portion of an MPM, the MPM Basic should command the Switch-portion to perform a hard reset.
3.8.2.2.1.3 No Text Found When commanded by the Host System (via SpaceWire) to reinitialize the Switch-portion flight software, the MPM Basic should command the Switch-portion to perform a soft reset.
3.8.2.3 Standby State and Modes No Text Found
3.8.2.3.1.1 No Text Found When an MPM initially enters the Standby State, it should enter Idle Mode.
3.8.2.3.1.2 No Text Found In the Standby State, an MPM should have only three Modes: Idle, Basic, and Diagnostic.
3.8.2.3.1.3 No Text Found In Standby State, all Mode changes should be commanded by the Host System. Note: A command may be sent to set a logic value in non-volatile MPM memory that if checked after an MPM entered Idle Mode would authorize that MPM to autonomously enter another valid Mode, such as Basic.
3.8.2.3.1.4 No Text Found An MPM should be capable of transitioning to the Standby State under the following conditions:

Sub-¶

Conditions

a.

From a power off condition after power is supplied to the Basic-portion only and receipt of a power-on command discrete from the Host System.

b.

When power is not applied to the Switch-portion.

3.8.2.3.1.7 No Text Found The MPM should use the Standby State, Diagnostic Mode to communicate with the Host System to diagnose and possibly resolve a problem with the MPM.
Note: Depending upon the problem, the MPM may be able to perform C&DH functions with Host System and the one or more payload.
3.8.2.4 Operational State and Mode No Text Found
3.8.2.4.1.1 No Text Found The MPM should be in the Standby State and Basic Mode before transitioning to the Operational State.
Note: When the transition to the Operational State occurs, the MPM would be in its Basic Mode.
3.8.2.4.1.2 No Text Found In the Operational State, a normally operating MPM should be able to achieve the following Modes:

3.8.2.4.1.3 No Text Found Unless it is the direct result of an autonomous fault management action, the MPM should only change Modes upon the receipt of a SpaceWire command to do so from the Host System.
3.8.2.4.1.4 No Text Found The MPM should complete Switch-portion initialization before entering into Active Mode.
3.8.2.4.1.5 No Text Found The MPM should support mission data switching while in the Active Mode and Diagnostic Mode.
3.8.2.4.1.6 No Text Found The MPM should not switch mission data while in the Idle, Basic or Monitor Mode.
Note: The switching of mission data while the MPM is in Diagnostic Mode is not recommended but may be feasible depending upon the reason(s) for being in Diagnostic Mode.
3.8.2.4.1.7 No Text Found When two MPMs are functioning properly in a Hot-Hot configuration, one MPM should be in the Operational State and Active Mode while the other is in the Operational State and Monitor Mode.
Note: If an MPM is designed as a single-thread unit, this requirement may not be testable at the unit level; however, it would be testable if the test equipment emulated the “other” MPM or if the MPM was designed as a dual-thread unit.
3.8.2.4.1.8 No Text Found While operating in the Hot-Hot configuration, the MPM currently in Monitor Mode should receive from the MPM in Active Mode all of the Host System and payload state and telemetry information necessary for the Monitor Mode MPM to, upon detection of a fault in the Active Mode MPM, subsume the role of an Active MPM within the transition period (e.g., 1 second) required by the mission.
3.8.2.4.1.9 No Text Found While operating in the Hot-Hot configuration, the MPM currently in Active Mode should set and maintain its MPM Active OUT discrete to a logic 0 until it detects an internal fault (e.g., watchdog timeout, double-bit memory error).
3.8.2.4.1.10 No Text Found While operating in the Hot-Hot configuration, when the Active Mode MPM detects an internal fault warranting setting its MPM Active OUT discrete to logic 1, it should within 1 ms - set its MPM_Fault discrete signals to the Host System to logic 1.
3.8.2.4.1.11 No Text Found While operating in the Hot-Hot configuration, when the Monitor MPM detects a logic 1 from its MPM Active IN discrete, it should immediately set its MPM Active OUT discrete to a logic 0 until it detects an internal fault (e.g., watchdog timeout, double-bit memory error).
3.8.2.4.1.12 No Text Found When two MPMs are functioning properly in a Hot-Warm configuration, one MPM should be in the Operational State and Active Mode while the other is in the Standby State and Idle Mode.
3.8.2.4.1.13 No Text Found When in a Hot-Cold configuration, one MPM should be powered off while the other is in a valid state and Mode.
3.9 MPM Timekeeping No Text Found
3.9.1 Clocks and Timers No Text Found
3.9.1.1 MPM Watchdog Timer No Text Found
3.9.1.1.1.1 No Text Found The MPM should contain a watchdog timer operated with a clock frequency of 40.92 MHz (+/- 0.025 ppm).
3.9.1.1.1.2 No Text Found The MPM watchdog timer should accommodate maximum count duration of 2 seconds.
3.9.1.1.1.3 No Text Found The MPM watchdog timer timeout count should be programmable via command.
3.9.1.1.1.4 No Text Found The MPM should generate a maskable interrupt when the watchdog timer reaches the maximum timeout count.
3.9.1.2 MPM Timekeeping Clock No Text Found
3.9.1.2.1.1 No Text Found The MPM should contain a timekeeping clock operated with a clock frequency of 40.92 MHz (+/- 0.025 ppm) and a maximum clock time of no less than 10 years.
3.9.1.2.1.2 No Text Found The MPM timekeeping clock should be settable periodically via command.
3.9.1.2.1.3 No Text Found The MPM timekeeping clock should be reset via command.
3.9.1.2.1.4 No Text Found The MPM timekeeping clock should rollover to 0 when it reaches the maximum clock time of 10 years.
3.9.1.3 MPM Auxiliary Timer No Text Found
3.9.1.3.1.1 No Text Found The MPM should contain an auxiliary timer operated with a clock frequency of 40.92 MHz (+/- 0.025 ppm).
3.9.1.3.1.2 No Text Found The MPM auxiliary timer should accommodate a maximum count duration of 2 seconds.
3.9.1.3.1.3 No Text Found The MPM auxiliary timer timeout count should be programmable via command.
3.9.1.3.1.4 No Text Found The MPM should generate a maskable interrupt when the auxiliary timer reaches the maximum timeout count.
3.9.1.4 Host System Domain Time Counter The Host System Domain Time Counter resides within the MPM and is used to retain a local copy of a time sourced by the Host System. If necessary, the MPM can provide that time to one or more payload for its use and/or for the payload to maintain that time locally. The MPM could synchronize the time with a payload by providing it an approaching time value to the payload and then asserting the appropriate PL_Time_Sync_NL signal when that exact time occurred.
3.9.1.4.1.1 No Text Found The MPM Host System Domain Time Counter should use a clock frequency of 40.92 MHz (+/- 0.025 ppm).
3.9.1.4.1.2 No Text Found The MPM should include a 54-bit Host System Domain Time Counter load register.
3.9.1.4.1.3 No Text Found The MPM should include a 54-bit Host System Domain Time Counter loadable by the Host System Domain Time Counter load register.
3.9.1.4.1.4 No Text Found The MPM 54-bit Host System Domain Time Counter load register should be able to load its value into a 54-bit Host System Domain Time Counter within 25 ns when enabled by the MPM at the assertion of the HS_Time_Sync_NL signal.
3.9.1.4.1.5 No Text Found The MPM should include a 54-bit Host System Domain Time Counter read register.
3.9.1.4.1.6 No Text Found The MPM Host System Domain Time Counter should be loadable and readable by the MPM processor.
3.9.1.4.1.7 No Text Found The Host System Domain Time Counter 54-bit register should interface with a re-programmable 54-bit comparator.
3.9.1.4.1.8 No Text Found The MPM processor should be able to load a 54-bit comparison value into the 54-bit Host System Domain Time Counter comparator.
3.9.1.4.1.9 No Text Found The 54-bit comparator should have an output signal routable, when enabled, to individually and also collectively drive any MPM processor selected combination of PL_Time_Sync_NL signals.
3.9.1.5 Auxiliary Payload Time Counter The Auxiliary Payload Time Counter resides within the MPM and is used to retain a local copy of a time sourced by a payload (e.g., an atomic clock source). If necessary, the MPM can provide that time to one or more payloads for immediate use or for the payload to maintain that time locally. The MPM could synchronize the time with a different payload by providing it an approaching time value and then asserting the target payloads PL_Time_Sync_NL signal when that exact time occurs. Similarly, the MPM can also provide the Auxiliary Payload Time Counter value to the Host System so it could also be synchronized to the payload time clock.
3.9.1.5.1.1 No Text Found The MPM PL Time Clock counter should use a clock frequency of 40.92 MHz (+/- 0.025 ppm).
3.9.1.5.1.2 No Text Found The MPM should include a 54-bit Auxiliary Payload Time Counter load register.
3.9.1.5.1.3 No Text Found The MPM should include a 54-bit Auxiliary Payload Time Counter loadable by the PL Time Clock load register.
3.9.1.5.1.4 No Text Found The MPM 54-bit Auxiliary Payload Time Counter load register should be able to load its value into a 54-bit Auxiliary Payload Time Counter when enabled by the MPM and at the assertion of the PL_Time_Sync_NL signal.
3.9.1.5.1.5 No Text Found The MPM should include a 54-bit Auxiliary Payload Time Counter read register.
3.9.1.5.1.6 No Text Found The MPM Auxiliary Payload Time Counter should be loadable and readable by the MPM processor.
3.9.1.5.1.7 No Text Found The Auxiliary Payload Time Counter 54-bit register should interface with a re-programmable 54-bit comparator.
3.9.1.5.1.8 No Text Found The MPM processor should be able to load a 54-bit comparison value into the 54-bit Auxiliary Payload Time Counter comparator.
3.9.1.5.1.9 No Text Found The 54-bit comparator should have an output signal routable, when enabled by the MPM, to individually and also collectively drive any MPM processor selected combination of PL_Time_Sync_NL signals.
3.9.1.5.1.10 No Text Found The 54-bit comparator should have an output signal that, when enabled by the MPM, asserts the Aux_Time_Sync_NL discrete to the Host System.
3.10 MPM Computation Resources No Text Found
3.10.1 Computational Throughput Capacity No Text Found
3.10.1.1.1.1 No Text Found The MPM Basic-portion should provide no less than 3.514E6 Dhrystones per second (2000 MIPS).
Note: In addition to command and data handling functions, this processing capability includes significant computational throughput capacity reserve for planned but not yet solidified cyber functions that would need to be completed within short periods of time.
3.10.1.1.1.2 No Text Found The MPM Switch-portion should provide no less than 3.514E6 Dhrystones per second (2000 MIPS).
Note: In addition to controlling Switch functions and communicating with the Basic-portion, this capability includes significant computational throughput capacity reserve for planned but not yet solidified cyber functions that would need to be completed within short periods of time.
3.10.2 Memory Capacity No Text Found
3.10.2.1.1.1 No Text Found The MPM Basic-portion should provide no less than 4 GBytes of volatile memory.
3.10.2.1.1.2 No Text Found The MPM Basic-portion should provide no less than 1 GBytes of non-volatile memory.
3.10.2.1.1.3 No Text Found The MPM Switch-portion should provide no less than 1 GBytes of volatile memory.
3.10.2.1.1.4 No Text Found The MPM Switch-portion should provide no less than 1 GBytes of non-volatile memory.

3.12 MPM Reliability No Text Found

3.12.1.1.1.1 No Text Found The MPM, as a single-thread unit operating over an 8 year mission, should have a probability of success of 0.7044 (or greater) over the operating life based on the performance criteria, environments, 100% duty cycle, and design considerations in this specification.
Note: A dual-redundant unit using standby redundancy should have a probability of 0.9499 or greater and a dual-redundant unit using active redundancy should have a probability of 0.9126 or greater.
3.12.1.1.1.2 No Text Found The unit design should use failure rates based upon a mission average baseplate temperature of 55 deg C.

3.13 Environmental Requirements No Text Found
3.13.1 Survivability No Text Found
3.13.1.1 Overview The MPM should be designed to function properly and meet performance requirements during and after exposure to the natural space radiation environment for an 8-year mission in the following orbits: LEO, MEO, GEO, and HEO. In addition, the MPM must function properly and meet performance requirements during and after exposure to a specific manmade radiation threat environment. Radiation environments are provided in Section 3.13.1.2 and requirements associated with those environments are given in Section 3.13.1.3.
3.13.1.2 Radiation Environments No Text Found
3.13.1.2.1 Total Ionizing Dose and Displacement Damage Fluence

The radiation environment from all sources for total ionizing dose (TID) is presented in Table 8 in terms of TID in rad(Si) versus Al shielding thickness. The radiation environment from all sources for displacement damage (DD) is also presented in that table in terms of 1-MeV-equivalent neutron fluence versus Al shielding thickness.  The TID and DD values in Table 8 are based on the survivability specification for the GPS program, scaled to an 8-year mission life. That specification includes a hostile component. For missions with more stringent TID and DD environments, the MPM must be designed to meet those more restrictive requirements. For example, shielding can be added to a unit to reduce the transported radiation environment to achieve TID and DD values below those in Table 8. Alternatively, MPM components can be demonstrated, by testing and/or analysis, that they meet radiation requirements in a more restrictive environment.

3.13.1.2.2 Environments for Single-Event Effects The MPM must meet performance and radiation requirements in the following environments that produce single-event effects (SEE) in devices, circuits, and electronic units.
3.13.1.2.2.1 No Text Found For background galactic cosmic rays (GCRs), the GEO environment, as specified by CREME96, should be used with 100 mils of Al shielding for all orbits.
3.13.1.2.2.2 No Text Found For solar particle events (SPE), one worst week at GEO, as specified by CREME96, should be used with 100 mils of Al shielding for all orbits.
3.13.1.2.2.3 No Text Found For background and solar protons, the environments specified by CREME96 for the above GCR and SPE conditions for GEO should be used for all orbits.
3.13.1.2.2.4 No Text Found For missions with more stringent trapped proton environments than GPS (environment reference only), the MPM should be designed to meet those more restrictive requirements for specified orbits.
3.13.1.2.2.5 No Text Found CREME96 should be used with 100 mils of Al shielding to determine the environment and event rates for electronic devices that are sensitive to trapped proton induced SEE.
3.13.1.2.3 Manmade Threat Environment No Text Found
3.13.1.2.3.1 No Text Found If an MPM is required to operate in a manmade environment, the manmade radiation threat environment specified in MIL-STD-3053 (Satellite Systems Natural and Nuclear Environment Standard) should be used.
3.13.1.2.3.2 No Text Found If the manmade threat environment is not given in MIL-STD-3053 for a specified orbit, then the manmade environment for the worst-case orbit in MIL-STD-3053 should be assumed, unless otherwise directed by the sponsoring agency.
3.13.1.3 Radiation Requirements No Text Found
3.13.1.3.1 Requirements for Total Ionizing Dose and Displacement Damage Effects No Text Found
3.13.1.3.1.1 No Text Found Electronic devices used in the MPM should meet all performance requirements with a probability of 0.9999 at a confidence level of 90%, based on small-sample statistics, when exposed to the total ionizing dose and 1-MeV-equivalent neutron fluence received during the mission by parts for their specific shielding configurations, unless directed otherwise by the sponsoring agency.
3.13.1.3.1.2 No Text Found Radiation exposure levels presented in Table 8 should be used for this purpose with no additional radiation design margin (RDM) applied (i.e., RDM = 1).
3.13.1.3.1.3 No Text Found All electronic devices used in the MPM should meet performance requirements after exposure to at least 1X the TID plus at least 1X the displacement damage exposure levels given in Table 8.
3.13.1.3.2 Requirements for Single-Event Effects SEUs and SETs are nondestructive. SEFIs are also nondestructive but typically require cycling the power to restore proper operation. SEB, SEGR, SEDR, and SHE are destructive single-event effects. Destructive single-event effects are defined as any SEE that causes a failure, or a damaging or unrecoverable latch-up or upset condition, or some other permanent damage that prevents performance specifications from being met. SEL can be either destructive or nondestructive. In the nondestructive SEL case, power cycling is required to restore proper functionality.
3.13.1.3.2.1 No Text Found The follow types of single-event effects should be accounted for in meeting requirements: single-event upset (SEU), single-event transients (SETs), single-event functional interrupt (SEFI), single-event latch-up (SEL), single-event burnout (SEB), single-event gate rupture (SEGR), single-event dielectric rupture (SEDR), and single-event hard errors (SHE) (also referred to as stuck bits).
3.13.1.3.2.2 No Text Found Electronic devices that exhibit destructive single-event effects at a threshold LET (linear energy transfer) 37 MeV-cm2/mg should not be used.
3.13.1.3.2.3 No Text Found Electronic devices that exhibit destructive single-event effects at a threshold LET > 75 MeV-cm2/mg should be acceptable for use as-is.
3.13.1.3.2.4 No Text Found Electronic devices that exhibit destructive single-event effects at a threshold LET in the range from > 37 to 75 MeV-cm2/mg should not be used unless it is demonstrated that the failure rate for a specific device can be accommodated within the reliability budget for the unit. For such assessments, destructive SEEs can be treated as random failures.
3.13.1.3.2.5 No Text Found Electronic devices that exhibit nondestructive SEL at a LET 75 MeV-cm2/mg should be reported to the program.
3.13.1.3.2.6 No Text Found Electronic devices that exhibit nondestructive SEL at a LET 75 MeV-cm2/mg that are reported to the program should be evaluated for use on a case-by-case basis.
3.13.1.3.2.7 No Text Found Electronic devices that exhibit nondestructive SEL at a LET 75 MeV-cm2/mg and are reported for potential use by the program should have an appropriate SEL mitigation procedure identified as part of that evaluation.
3.13.1.3.2.8 No Text Found Electronic parts should be selected to minimize errors due to SEUs, SETs, and SEFIs.
3.13.1.3.2.9 No Text Found The unit using the selected parts should comply with its program SEE rate allocation with respect to event rates requiring external intervention for recovery.
3.13.1.3.2.10 No Text Found For nondestructive SEEs in electronic devices that require ground intervention for recovery, the MPM should exhibit an overall rate of less than or equal to 0.1 event/year.
3.13.1.3.2.11 No Text Found FPGAs and ASICs should implement SEE mitigation techniques (e.g., EDAC, memory scrubbing, and TMR) when needed to meet program ground intervention requirements.
3.13.1.3.2.12 No Text Found Discrete high-voltage power transistors, including MOS and bipolar devices, that are susceptible to SEB, SEGR, or SEDR should maintain operating voltages 75% of their respective SEE safe operating areas based on information in manufacturers datasheets.
3.13.1.3.3 Requirements for Manmade Radiation Environment Effects No Text Found
3.13.1.3.3.1 No Text Found The manmade radiation threat requirements specified in MIL-STD-3053 (Satellite Systems Natural and Nuclear Environment Standard) should be used.
3.13.1.3.3.2 No Text Found If the mission radiation survivability requirements are not included in MIL-STD-3053 for a specified orbit, the requirements for the worst-case orbit in MIL-STD-3053 should be assumed unless otherwise directed by the sponsoring agency.
3.13.1.3.3.3 No Text Found The MPM should be designed to be hardened against derived SGEMP levels based on the manmade environments given in MIL-STD-3053.
3.13.1.3.4 Electrostatic Discharge Control No Text Found
3.13.1.3.4.1 No Text Found The MPM should have no more than 0.01-cm2 surface area of ungrounded metal within 100 mils of an electrostatic discharge (ESD) sensitive part.
Note: Ungrounded is defined as there being greater than 10-MW of resistance between the floating metal and the chassis electrical ground or electrical power return.
3.13.1.3.4.2 No Text Found The CMP should have no more than 0.2-cm2 of surface area for ungrounded metal greater than 100 mils from an electrostatic discharge sensitive part.
Note 1: Ungrounded is defined as there being greater than 10-MW of resistance between the floating metal and the chassis electrical ground or electrical power return.
Note 2: This floating metal requirement does not prevent electrostatic discharges.  It reduces the size of the electrostatic discharges to 0.7 mJ, and the energy is dependent on the dielectric constant, thickness, and breakdown strength.
3.13.1.3.4.3 No Text Found All radiation spot shields, on parts inside the MPM, should be grounded.
3.13.1.3.4.4 No Text Found The MPM should survive all discharges from deep dielectric charging.
3.13.1.3.4.5 No Text Found An electrostatic discharge control program meeting the requirements of ANSI/ESDA 20.20 or equivalent should be maintained for all parts, units, and assemblies during acquisition, storage, assembly, integration, and test.
3.13.1.3.4.6 No Text Found The MPM should be designed so that the electron flux normally incident on ungrounded metals and/or insulators is 0.1 pA/ cm2 (6.25E5 electrons/cm2/s); or, the minimum shielding provided by the MPM housing and the spacecraft structure (if the equipment is located wholly within the spacecraft structure) is equal to or greater than 120 mil of equivalent aluminum.
Note: This does not prevent all electrostatic discharges from floating metal but does reduce it to a small rate.  These electrostatic discharges still may upset the circuits that are not designed to operate through these electrostatic discharges.

3.13.1.3.4.8 No Text Found Electrical interfaces that connect to wiring where any portion of the wiring passes outside of the spacecraft faraday cage should not be damaged nor permanently degraded by exposure to ESD transients with a source equivalent to [MIL-STD-883L], class 2 (human body Mode, 100 pF, 2000 volts, 1500 ohm).
Note: [MIL-STD-883L] Class 2 envelopes the worst case expected cable discharge voltage and energy. The prime is responsible for defining any MPM interfaces that meet these criteria.
3.13.1.3.4.9 No Text Found Exposed dielectric surfaces and electrically isolated conductive surfaces, such as clamps, inserts, or other small components should be permitted provided that the total surface area does not exceed 3 cm2.
Note: Larger areas are permitted where it can be shown that any resulting discharges will not degrade operation of any spacecraft subsystems or equipment.
3.13.1.3.4.10 No Text Found A static discharge path should be provided for all ESD conductive materials.
3.13.1.3.4.11 No Text Found Unless otherwise required by this document, the DC resistance of such static discharge path(s) should not exceed 106 ohms measured between the ESD conductive surface and the spacecraft ground plane.
3.13.1.3.4.12 No Text Found The MPM should not use anodized finishes on surfaces exceeding 3 cm2 and are either exposed to space or separated from space only by a thermal blanket.
