3.13.2.1.1.2 No Text Found Verification of conducted emissions should be in accordance with the MIL-STD-461G CE101 test method.
3.13.2.2 Conducted Susceptibility, Primary Power Leads (CS101/02) No Text Found
3.13.2.2.1.1 No Text Found The unit should meet all performance requirements when the primary power leads are subjected to the conducted susceptibility limit specified in Figure 12. The CS101 requirement is also met when the power source is adjusted to dissipate the power level shown in Figure 13 into a 0.5 Ohm load and the unit is not susceptible. The CS02 requirement is also met when a 1-watt source of 50 Ohms cannot develop the required voltage at the unit power inputs.
3.13.2.2.1.2 No Text Found Verification of conducted susceptibility should be in accordance with the TOR-2005(8583)-1A CS101 and CS02 test methods.
3.13.2.3 Conducted Susceptibility, Short Transients, Primary Power Leads (CS06) No Text Found

E() = 200 V and pulse width t() = 10 s +/-20%.
3.13.2.3.1.2 No Text Found Verification should be in accordance with the TOR-2005(8583)-1A CS06 test method.

3.13.2.6 Radiated Emissions, Magnetic Field (RE101) No Text Found
3.13.2.6.1.1 No Text Found Radiated emissions from the unit and interconnecting wires should meet the limit specified in Figure 17.

3.13.2.7 Radiated Emission, Electric Field (RE102) No Text Found
3.13.2.7.1.1 No Text Found Radiated emissions from the unit and interconnecting wires should meet the limit specified in Figure 18. The requirements in the figure assume a 20 dB Faraday cage is provided by the vehicle structure from 14 KHz to 40 GHz. Applications with a reduced or no Faraday cage should lower the limit in Figure 18 by the difference between 20 dB and the actual shielding effectiveness. Measurements below the spectrum analyzer noise floor with the lowest possible resolution bandwidth are acceptable even if they do not meet the requirement.
3.13.2.7.1.2 No Text Found Verification should be in accordance with the MIL-STD-461G RE102 test method.
3.13.2.8 Radiated Susceptibility, AC and DC Magnetic Field (RS101) No Text Found
3.13.2.8.1.1 No Text Found The unit should meet all performance requirements when subjected to the radiated susceptibility limit specified in Figure 19 and a DC limit of 5 gauss.
3.13.2.8.1.2 No Text Found Verification of radiated susceptibility should be in accordance with the MIL-STD-461G RS101 test method.
Note: The DC verification test method will require some modification of the RS101 test method.
3.13.2.9 Radiated Susceptibility, Electric Field (RS103) No Text Found
3.13.2.9.1.1 No Text Found The unit should meet all performance requirements when subjected to the radiated susceptibility limit specified in Figure 20. The requirements in the figure assume a 20 dB Faraday cage is provided by the vehicle structure from 14 kHz to 40 GHz. Applications with a reduced or no Faraday cage should increase the limit in Figure 20 by the difference between 20 dB and the actual shielding effectiveness or 200 V/m, whichever is less.
3.13.2.9.1.2 No Text Found Verification of radiated susceptibility should be in accordance with the MIL-STD-461G RS103 test method.
3.13.3 Thermal No Text Found
3.13.3.1 Heat Transfer No Text Found
3.13.3.1.1.1 No Text Found Heat transfer to and from the MPM should be by conduction through the baseplate with no reliance on radiation.
3.13.3.2 Baseplate Thermal Load The MPM will be mounted to a host vehicle platform which will accommodate the MPM waste heat and provide baseplate temperature control.
3.13.3.2.1.1 No Text Found The heat transfer flux between the MPM baseplate and the spacecraft surface to which it mounts should not exceed 1.5 W/in2 at any point on the mounting surface.
3.13.3.3 Emittance No Text Found
3.13.3.3.1.1 No Text Found External surfaces of the MPM, except for the mounting surface and connectors, should have an emittance of 0.8 or greater.

3.14 Mission Assurance Requirements No Text Found
3.14.1 Quality Assurance Program No Text Found
3.14.1.1.1.1 No Text Found A space qualified Quality Assurance program should be maintained from first acquisition through completed MPM delivery.
3.14.2 Parts, Materials and Processes No Text Found
3.14.2.1.1.1 No Text Found A qualified parts materials and processes list should be prepared for design use in parts, materials and processes selection.
3.14.2.1.1.2 No Text Found Parts should be space qualified meeting Class S or equivalent requirements.
3.14.2.1.1.3 No Text Found PWBs and circuit cards should be space qualified.
3.14.2.1.1.4 No Text Found Materials used in unit production should be space qualified and within their designated shelf lives.
3.14.2.1.1.5 No Text Found Space level traceability should be maintained.
3.14.3 Design Analysis Requirements No Text Found
3.14.3.1 Worst-Case Analysis No Text Found
3.14.3.1.1.1 No Text Found Worst-Case Analysis (WCA) should be performed on the MPM to verify the design would meet system performance specification over design life under worst-case conditions and tolerances (initial, aging, radiation, and temperature).
3.14.3.2 Worst-Case Circuit Analysis No Text Found
3.14.3.2.1.1 No Text Found Worst-Case Circuit Analysis (WCCA) should be performed to verify the circuitry within the MPM would work as intended given that each constituent part is subject to worst-case conditions and tolerances (initial, aging, radiation, voltages, timing, and temperature).
3.14.3.3 Reliability Analysis No Text Found
3.14.3.3.1.1 No Text Found Reliability analysis should be performed to calculate the probability of success of the MPM over its design or mission life based on failure rates of parts, taking into account the redundancy and cross-strapping provisions in the MPM.
3.14.3.4 Failure Modes and Effects Analysis No Text Found
3.14.3.4.1.1 No Text Found Failure Mode and Effect Analysis (FMEA) should be performed to verify the impacts of the MPM to the system based on various Modes and to identify Single-Point Failures of the MPM.
3.14.3.5 Single Event Effects No Text Found
3.14.3.5.1.1 No Text Found Single Event Effects (SEE) Analysis should be performed to evaluate solid-state devices used in the MPM design as to the rate at which they would experience Single Event Upsets (SEU), Single Event Transients (SET), or other responses to the proton or heavy-ion environment on-orbit, and the related circuit-level effects.
3.14.3.6 Thermal Analysis No Text Found
3.14.3.6.1.1 No Text Found Thermal Analysis should be performed to predict the range of temperatures that the MPM would encounter at the unit baseplate, across the surfaces of the circuit cards or modules, individual component case temperatures, and junction temperature rise in solid-state components, and to produce the heat flux per area for the MPM.
3.14.3.7 Radiation and Life Analysis of Parts No Text Found
3.14.3.7.1.1 No Text Found Radiation and Life Analysis should be performed to determine part parameter variations over the life of the parts used in the MPM.
3.14.4 Failure Reporting and Corrective Action System (FRACAS) No Text Found
3.14.4.1.1.1 No Text Found Using a space qualified system, records of failures and corrective actions implemented should be maintained throughout developmental assembly and testing of MPM.
4 Verification This section defines a set of verification methods for each requirement in Section 3 of the MOSA Payload Manager (MPM) Guide. A matrix is used to suggest verification method(s) for each requirement to verify it has been met.
4.1 Verification Methods No Text Found
4.1.1 Analysis (A) Verifies requirement compliance based on analytical methods and techniques (e.g., mathematical calculations, modeling & simulation results, empirical studies).
4.1.2 Test (T) Verifies requirement compliance based on an items explicit measures of performance during exposure to applicable required stimulus and environment. There may be cases where it is necessary for performance measurements to be coupled with analysis and/or demonstration.
4.1.3 Inspection (I) Verifies requirement compliance of observable (e.g., visible, sound, feel) physical interfaces and characteristics (e.g., construction features, finish, identification markings and cleanliness) of an item without the use of specialized equipment. Inspection can also include inspection of drawings, documents, or other records.
4.1.4 Demonstration (D) Verifies requirement compliance of hardware and/or software based observable behavior while performing in a simulation or simulated operational configuration.
4.1.5 Similarity Verifies requirement compliance (usually in combination with analysis) based on an item’s equivalency to another item that has been qualified to equivalent or more stringent criteria.  This verification method consists of assessment and review of hardware configuration, hardware application and prior test data including a comparison of prior test levels with new specific requirements.  Differences in configuration, application or test conditions usually require analyses and additional testing to complete verification by the method of similarity.

MPM Input Power

 

 

 

 

3.2.1.1.1.1

The MPM Basic-portion should operate over an input voltage range of 24 VDC to 105 VDC.

X

 

X

 

3.2.1.1.1.2

The MPM Basic-portion should accept separate, current limited, switched primary power from the Host System.

X

The MPM Switch-portion should operate over an input voltage range of 24 VDC to 105 VDC.

X

 

X

 

3.2.1.1.1.4

The MPM Switch-portion should accept separate, current limited, switched primary power from the Host System.

X

 

 

 

3.2.1.1.2

Passive Analog (Resistive)

 

 

 

 

3.2.1.1.2.1

A Passive Analog (Resistive) signal should provide a resistive impedance ranging from 1190K Ohms to 425 Ohms.

X

 

X

 

3.2.1.1.2.2

The Passive Analog (Resistive) signal should provide 5K Ohms resistance at ambient temperature (i.e., 25 degrees Celsius).

X

 

X

 

3.2.1.1.3

Active Analog

 

 

 

 

3.2.1.1.3.1

An Active Analog output signal should provide a maximum voltage range between +10 VDC and -10 VDC.

X

 

X

 

3.2.1.1.3.2

Each Active analog signal should be a single-ended signal, with a return.

X

X

 

 

3.2.1.1.3.3

Each non-return Active Analog signal should have a series resistance of 10k ohm between its interface connector pin and its internal signal source.

X

 

X

 

3.2.1.1.3.4

The load resistance of each Active Analog signal input should be a minimum of 1 Mega-Ohms.

X

 

 

 

3.2.1.1.3.5

The load capacitance of each Active Analog signal input should be a maximum of 200 pico-Farad shunt capacitance.

X

 

 

 

3.2.1.1.4

Discrete Signal Interface

 

 

 

 

3.2.1.1.4.1

Each LVDS Command and Telemetry Discrete signal should be in compliance with the ANSI/TIA/EIA-644 Standard.

X

X

 

 

3.2.1.1.4.2

Each LVDS Command and Telemetry Discrete signal should be driven and received by a 3.3V LVDS driver and receiver.

 

X

X

 

3.2.1.1.4.3

Each LVDS signal should be a balanced differential with the circuit referenced to secondary power ground at the transmitting and receiving ends.

 

X

 

 

3.2.1.1.4.4

Each LVDS discrete command driver should drive a Logic 1 as the default style='' style='' style='' style='' output.

X

 

X

 

3.2.1.1.4.5

Impedance controlled 100 Ohms (+/- 6 Ohms) wire should be used in the MPM harness (in compliance with ANSI/TIA/EIA-644) to match the LVDS receiver 100 Ohm termination resistor.

 

X

 

 

3.2.1.1.4.6

The LVDS Common-Mode Voltage (VCM) should be +1.2V +/- 1V.

X

 

X

 

3.2.1.1.4.7

The LVDS receiver differential input threshold levels should be +/-100mV with respect to the Common-Mode Voltage (VCM). 

X

 

X

 

3.2.1.1.4.8

Upon the application of MPM power, the initial state of each LVDS external interface output signal should be de-asserted.

X

 

X

 

3.2.1.1.4.9

Each LVDS driver and receiver should have inherent cold-spare capabilities (i.e., high impedance or otherwise provide current limiting) such that MPM LVDS device output circuitry stress is prevented when the MPM and the unit it interfaces with via LVDS operate in a Hot-Cold redundancy configuration.

X

 

 

 

3.2.1.1.4.10

Each LVDS discrete command receiver input should default style='' style='' style='' style='' to a logic 1 when not actively driven.

3.3

Chassis Requirements

 

 

 

 

3.3.1

Chassis General Requirements

 

 

 

 

3.3.1.1.1.1

A single aluminum chassis should house the MPM subassemblies.

 

X

 

 

3.3.1.1.1.2

The MPM chassis walls should have a minimum thickness of 125 mils.   Note: MPM chassis wall thickness may vary depending upon the mission required radiation environment.

 

X

 

 

3.3.1.1.1.3

A single-thread MPM chassis envelope should be less than or equal to 15.5” length, 13.3” width, 10.1” height.

 

X

 

 

3.3.1.1.1.4

The MPM should have a weight no greater than 61.5 pounds. 

Note: The above weight is for a single-thread MPM with two (2) spare (empty) slots and assumes a mounting placement on the vehicle that provides no shielding that might otherwise reduce the MPM chassis wall thickness and resulting chassis/unit weight.  Depending upon the unit placement within the vehicle, the single-thread unit weight could be significantly lower - in the neighborhood of 45 pounds.

 

X

X

 

3.3.1.1.1.5

The MPM center of gravity should be verified to an accuracy of 0.15 inches in the X-Y-Z axis.

X

 

X

 

3.3.1.1.1.6

The MPM mass moment of inertia should be determined to an accuracy of 5 percent.

X

 

 

 

3.3.1.1.1.7

The MPM minimum natural frequency should be greater than 110 Hz.

X

 

X

 

3.3.1.1.1.8

The MPM mounting surface should have a flatness less than or equal to 0.010 in. over the longest dimension.

 

X

 

 

3.3.1.1.1.9

Except for its mounting surface, the MPM chassis external finish should have a black coating with hemispherical emissivity coating greater than or equal to 0.80.

 

X

 

 

3.3.1.1.1.10

The MPM chassis SpaceVPX type should be FLT (flight, or flight equivalent).

 

X

 

 

3.3.1.1.1.11

The MPM chassis should include two separate major portions, one referred to as the Basic-portion and the other as the Switch-portion.

 

 

X

 

 

3.3.2

Chassis Internal Requirements

 

 

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.1

The MPM chassis should include at least one (1) spare SpaceVPX payload slot in the Basic-portion.

Note: The Basic-portion spare slot is reserved for a cyber (e.g., zero trust architecture) function and/or as a resiliency or unique interface accommodation module; therefore, if such a board is installed into the MPM Basic-portion “spare slot”, the subject requirement remains satisfied.

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.2

The MPM chassis should include one (1) spare payload slot in the Switch-portion.

Note: The Switch-portion spare slot is reserved for a cyber (e.g., zero trust architecture) function; therefore, if the cyber function board is installed into the MPM Switch-portion “spare slot”, the subject requirement remains satisfied.

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.3

Each MPM internal digital plug-in module and the spare plug-in module should utilize a SpaceVPX 6U module profile per Section 12 of SpaceVPX.

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.4

The MPM should utilize a backplane for interconnecting internal digital and spare plug-in SpaceVPX modules.

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.5

All user defined pins on any internal digital plug-in SpaceVPX module and the spare plug-in module in the MPM should be inputs or be configurable to a non-driving state.

Note: All user defined pins that cannot meet this requirement should be fully documented as to output default style='' style='' style='' style='' state, voltage levels, interface type, current requirements, etc. This will maximize interoperability for future module upgrades inside the MPM.

X

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.6

MPM command and data handling between internal digital plug-in SpaceVPX modules (including the spare plug-in module) should utilize SpaceWire control planes per Section 5 of SpaceVPX.

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.7

MPM-low speed configuration and status between internal digital plug-in SpaceVPX modules including the spare module should utilize either System Management Interfaces on the Utility Plane per Section 3 and 5 of SpaceVPX, or SpaceWire control planes per Section 5 of SpaceVPX.

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.8

MPM System Management Interfaces on the Utility Plane should support register access through the Direct Access Protocol as defined in Section 3 and 5 of SpaceVPX.

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.9

MPM System Management Interfaces on the control plane should support RMAP access to DAP addressed registers as defined in the RMAP Protocol for SpaceWire [ECSS-E-ST-50-52C].

 

X

X

 

3.3.2.1.1.10

MPM data connections between internal digital plug-in SpaceVPX modules including the spare module should utilize either  Ethernet data plane interfaces per Section 5 of SpaceVPX or SpaceWire control plane interfaces per Section 5 of SpaceVPX.

 

X

X

 

3.3.2.1.1.11

MPM secondary grounds should be internally grounded to the chassis.

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.12

Impedance between internal grounds or between a connector shell and ground should be less than or equal to 2.5 milli-Ohms.

 

 

X

 

3.3.2.1.1.13

Chassis connector gender, type, and quantity should be as listed below:

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.13.a

Type: M83513/04-A

Pin count: 9

Gender: Socket

Quantity: 15

Notes: SpaceWire, MPM to Payload: 12, MPM to Host System: 2, MPM to 2nd MPM: 1

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.13.b

Type: M24308/23-162

Pin count: 26

Gender: Socket

Quantity: 2

Notes: Discrete Signals, MPM to/from Host System side A & B

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.13.c

Type: M24308/23-119

Pin count: 9

Gender: Socket

Quantity: 1

Notes: Discrete Signals, MPM to MPM

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.13.d

Type: M24308/23-165

Pin count: 78

Gender: Socket

Quantity: 3

Notes: Discrete Signals, MPM to/from Payloads: 3

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.13.e

Type: MicroSI, VERTICAL MOUNT

Pin count: 41

Gender:

Quantity: 12

Notes: ETH, MPM to Payload: 12

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.13.f

Type: M24308/24-152

Pin count: 37

Gender: Pin

Quantity: 2

Notes: Power: Switch 1, Basic 1

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.13.g

Type: M24308/23-151

Pin count: 25

Gender: Socket

Quantity: 2

Notes: Passive Analog: Switch 1,  Basic 1

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.14

Connectors, compression rings and back-shells should be made of metal with copper under-plating and nickel over-plating on all surfaces.

 

X

 

 

3.3.2.1.1.15

Connector receptacles should have enough spacing so any one connector can be mated or de-mated without requiring the mate or de-mate of a second connector or the removal of a mounted unit from the spacecraft.

X

X

 

 

3.4

MPM-Host System Interface Requirements

 

 

 

 

3.4.1

MPM-Host System Interface General Requirements

 

 

 

 

3.4.1.1.1.1

The MPM C&DH signals that interface with the Host System should be designed such that an interface short or open would not affect the functionality or performance of other MPM interfaces.

X

 

 

 

3.4.2

MPM-Host System Interface SpaceWire Interface

 

 

 

 

3.4.2.1

MPM-Host System Interface SpaceWire Interface Characteristics

 

 

 

 

3.4.2.1.1.1

The MPM SpaceWire physical layer interfaces used to communicate with the Host System should comply with the [ECSS-E-ST-50-12C, Rev. 1] SpaceWire Standard.

X

 

 

 

3.4.2.1.1.2

The MPM SpaceWire interface used to communicate with the Host System should support data transfer across a copper (wire) medium.

X

 

X

 

3.4.2.1.1.3

Each MPM SpaceWire used to interface with the Host System should be initialized for LinkStart.

X

 

X

 

3.4.2.1.1.4

After initialization, each MPM SpaceWire receive and transmit interface to the Host System should independently support a  data rate of 200 Mbps . Each MPM SpaceWire interface should be designed to preclude damage while it is off and being actively driven by its external interfacing equipment (e.g., Host System, or equivalent test interface). 

Note: Active voltage of +4.3V.

 

 

X

 

3.4.2.1.1.5

The MPM should not host a SpaceWire Switch to transfer information (e.g., commands, data) to or from the Host System.

Note 1: The MPM will receive, process, and, when necessary, individually forward commands and data to the Host System.  It is envisioned that the MPM will host a cyber-related capability to monitor all commands between the Host System and MPM, between MPM and Payload(s), and between MPMs; and a Switch would circumvent that capability. 

X

 

 

 

3.4.2.2

MPM-Host System Interface SpaceWire Quantity and Names

 

 

 

 

3.4.2.2.1.1

The MPM should provide two (2) SpaceWire unit connectors as part of its Host System interface.

Note: One will be dedicated to interface with the A-side of a Host System and the other dedicated to interface with a B-side of the Host System.

 

X

 

 

3.4.2.2.1.2

The MPM SpaceWire port used to communicate with the A-side of the Host System should be identified as SpW_A.

 

X

 

 

3.4.2.2.1.3

The MPM SpaceWire port used to communicate with the B-side of the Host System should be identified as SpW_B.

 

X

 

 

3.4.2.3

MPM-Host System Interface SpaceWire Connector

 

 

 

 

3.4.2.3.1.1

Each MPM MPM-to-Host System SpaceWire unit connector should be a rectangular, 9-pin, M83513 (e.g., /04) connector.

 

X

 

 

3.4.2.4

MPM-Host System Interface SpaceWire Connector Pinout

 

 

 

 

3.4.2.4.1.1

Each MPM-to-Host System SpaceWire unit connector should have the pinout specified in Table 1.

 

X

The MPM Basic-portion Host System interface should provide four redundant (qty. 8) Discrete Signal inputs.

 

X

Signal name: HS_Time_Sync_NL_B

Type: Discrete Signal

From Host System side: B

MPM Connector: M24308/23-162

 

X

 

 

3.4.3.1.1.3

Each LVDS receiver should have Failsafe Mode, so that the receiver output goes high whenever the interface is not driven, open circuit or short circuited. (Device example includes Aeroflex UT54LVDS032LV)

 

X

 

 

3.4.3.1.1.4

The LVDS input Common-Mode Voltage (VCM) should be +1.2V +/- 1V.

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.1.1.5

The LVDS receiver differential input threshold levels should be +/-100mV with respect to the Common-Mode Voltage (VCM).

X

 

X

3.4.3.5

MPM Input (from Host System) Discrete Signal Characteristics

 

 

 

 

3.4.3.5.1

MPM_Select_NL

 

 

 

 

3.4.3.5.1.1

The MPM should interpret its MPM_Select_NL discrete command input as asserted (selected) when the signal is a logic 0.

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.5.1.2

While the MPM_Select_NLA signal is asserted, the MPM should enable SpaceWire communication over SpaceWire port A (i.e., A-side of the Host System).

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.5.1.3

While the MPM_Select_NLA signal is de-asserted, the MPM should disable SpaceWire communication over SpaceWire port A.

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.5.1.4

While the MPM_Select_NLB signal is asserted, the MPM should enable SpaceWire communication over SpaceWire port B (i.e., B-side of the Host System).

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.5.1.5

While the MPM_Select_NLB signal is de-asserted, the MPM should disable SpaceWire communication over SpaceWire port B.

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.5.2

MPM_Hard_Reset_NL

 

 

 

 

3.4.3.5.2.1

The MPM should interpret its MPM_Hard_Reset_NL discrete command input as asserted (selected) when the signal is a logic 0 for 10 milliseconds (+/- 10%) and subsequently transitions to logic 1 for at least 10 milliseconds.

 

 

X

 

3.4.3.5.2.2

The MPM should interpret its MPM_Hard_Reset_NL discrete command input as de-asserted (de-selected) when the signal is a logic 1.

 

 

X

 

3.4.3.5.2.3

When the MPM_Hard_Reset_NL discrete command input is asserted (selected), the MPM should reset its internal cards to initial states and emulate a power on reset, without the need to interrupt the main power input to the MPM.

 

 

X

 

3.4.3.5.2.4

Upon detection of a valid MPM_Hard_Reset_NL, the MPM processor should reset its memory pointer to the first address of the Startup ROM, reset all timers, registers, processors, and interfaces.

 

 

X

 

3.4.3.5.2.5

After processing an MPM_Hard_Reset_NL, the MPM should enter the Idle Mode.

 

 

X

 

3.4.3.5.3

MPM_Soft_Reset_NL

 

 

 

 

3.4.3.5.3.1

When the MPM_Soft_Reset_NL C&DH interface signal is driven to logic 0 for 10 milliseconds (+/- 10%) and subsequently transitions to logic 1 for at least 10 milliseconds, the MPM should reload its operating system and flight software.

 

 

X

 

3.4.3.5.3.2

As part of the processing a soft reset interrupt, the MPM should initialize its SpaceWire interfaces with LinkStart enabled.

 

 

 

X

3.4.3.5.3.3

After processing an MPM_Soft_Reset_NL the MPM should enter the Idle Mode.

 

 

X

 

3.4.3.5.4

HS_Time_Sync_NL

 

 

 

 

3.4.3.5.4.1

The MPM should use the falling edge (logic 1 to logic 0 transition) of the HS_Time_Sync_NL signal to serve as the time of reference instance for synchronization.

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6

MPM Output (to HS-Host System Subsystem) Discrete Signal Characteristics

 

 

 

 

3.4.3.6.1

MPM_Ready_NL

 

 

 

 

3.4.3.6.1.1

Assertion of the MPM_Ready_NL discrete output should be logic 0.

X

 

 

 

3.4.3.6.1.2

The MPM should assert its MPM_Ready_NL discrete output after the following conditions have been met:

 

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.1.2.a

The MPM has successfully booted up

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.1.2.b

MPM has passed post-boot diagnostic tests

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.1.2.c

Local version of flight software ready for use

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.1.2.d

SpaceWire services are ready for operations

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.1.3

MPM_Ready_NL should be logic 1 when the MPM SpaceWire is not ready for operations or reset (Hard Reset or Soft Reset) occurs.

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.2

MPM_Fault

 

 

 

 

3.4.3.6.2.1

Assertion of the MPM_Fault discrete output should be logic 1.

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.2.2

The MPM_Fault discrete output should be asserted when it detects that any of the following conditions occur:

Note: An MPM RIO Switch_Fault is reported via SpaceWire telemetry.

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.2.2.a

SpaceWire communications with the Host System are not operational

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.2.2.b

MPM processor watchdog timer timeout

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.2.2.c

Detection of an uncorrectable memory error within the Basic-portion of the MPM

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.2.3

The MPM_Fault status should be clearable by SpaceWire command from the Host System. Note: There are multiple options for attempting to clear unit faults (e.g., unit reset [hard or soft], or command) and the method used may depend upon fault type.

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.2.4

The MPM should drive the MPM_Fault Telemetry Discrete Command to Logic 0 when there are no MPM faults to report to the Host System.

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.3

Aux_Time_Sync_NL

 

 

 

 

3.4.3.6.3.1

The MPM should use the falling edge of the Aux_Time_Sync_NL signal to serve as the time of reference instance for synchronization.

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.3.2

The assertion of Aux_Time_Sync_NL should have an accuracy of 25 ns or less relative to the falling edge of the clock used to maintain time within the MPM.

X

 

X

 

3.4.3.6.3.3

The MPM should de-assert its Aux_Time_Sync_NL at least 100 microseconds after assertion.

X

 

X

 

3.4.4

MPM-Host System Interface Power Interface

 

 

 

 

3.4.4.1

MPM Power Interface

 

 

 

 

3.4.4.1.1

MPM Power Interface, Type 1 (24-105V)

 

 

 

 

3.4.4.1.1.1

An MPM Type 1 should satisfy its specified performance requirements operating over an input voltage range between 24 VDC and 105 VDC.

 

 

X

 

3.4.4.1.1.2

Each MPM Type 1 power converter should have a DC source impedance of 20 m to 100 m.

X

 

 

 

3.4.4.1.1.3

The MPM Basic-portion with a Type 1 power interface should consume no more than 55 W maximum power. 

Note: Includes accommodation for the space plug-in module.

X

 

X

 

3.4.4.1.1.4

The MPM Switch-portion with a Type 1 power interface should consume no more than 115 W maximum power. 

Note: Includes accommodation for the space plug-in module.

X

 

X

 

3.4.4.1.1.5

Each MPM Type 1 power converter should meet a step inrush maximum of 5x maximum input current within 100 s and drop to 2.5x within 10 ms.

 

 

X

 

3.4.4.1.1.6

Each MPM Type 1 power converter should survive the application of input voltage ranging from 0 V to 115 V with no damage.

X

 

 

X

3.4.4.1.1.7

Each MPM Type 1 power converter should provide overcurrent limiting at 250% within 100 ms.

Note: the overcurrent set point must be greater than 200% to provide fuse blow margin in fuse Host System application.

X

 

 

X

3.4.4.1.1.8

Each MPM Type 1 power converter should provide independent overvoltage protection on the primary power input at input voltages in excess of 115 V.

X

 

 

X

3.4.4.1.1.9

Each MPM Type 1 power converter should operate from an input voltage ranging from 24 VDC to 105 VDC.

X

 

X

 

3.4.4.1.1.10

Each MPM Type 1 power converter should meet a step inrush maximum of 5x maximum input current within 100 s and drop to 2.5x within 10 ms.

 

 

 

X

3.4.4.1.1.11

Each MPM Type 1 power converter should survive the application of input voltage ranging from 0 V to 115 V indefinitely with no damage.

X

 

 

X

3.4.4.1.1.12

Each MPM Type 1 power converter that would provide power to MPM modules should provide overcurrent limiting at 200% within 100 ms.

X

 

 

X

3.4.4.1.1.13

Each MPM Type 1 power converter that would provide power to MPM modules should provide independent overvoltage limiting at 120% of nominal within 1 ms.

X

 

 

X

3.4.4.2

MPM Power Interface Connector

 

 

 

 

3.4.4.2.1.1

The primary power unit connector for the Basic-portion of each MPM should be a 37-pin micro-D subminiature (Part number: M24308/24-152).

 

X

 

 

3.4.4.2.1.2

The primary power unit connector for the Switchportion of each MPM should be a 37-pin micro-D subminiature (Part number: M24308/24-152).

3.4.5

MPM Host System Interface Passive Analog Interface

 

 

 

 

3.4.5.1

Passive Analog (Resistive) Interface Characteristics

Each MPM passive analog signal should be a single-ended signal, with a return.

 

X

X

X

X

X

 

3.4.5.2.1.2

There should be at least one thermal sensor in the Basic-portion of the MPM.

Note: Thermal sensors should be placed in close proximity to the hottest area of each portion of the MPM.

 

X

X

 

3.4.5.2.1.3

There should be at least one thermal sensor in the Switch-portion of the MPM.

Note: Thermal sensors should be placed in close proximity to the hottest area of each portion of the MPM.

 

X

X

3.5

MPM Payload-Interface Requirements

 

 

 

 

3.5.1

MPM Payload-Interface General Requirements

 

 

 

 

3.5.1.1.1.1

The MPM payload interfaces should be designed such that an external interface short or open should not affect the functionality of other MPM interfaces.

X

 

 

 

3.5.2

MPM Payload-Interface SpaceWire Interface

 

 

 

 

3.5.2.1.1.1

The MPM payload physical layer interfaces should comply with the [ECSS-E-ST-50-12C, Rev. 1] SpaceWire Standard.

 

X

X

 

3.5.2.1.1.2

After initialization, each MPM to Payload SpaceWire receive and transmit interface should independently support a  data rate of 200 Mbps .

 

 

X

 

3.5.2.1.1.3

Each MPM to Payload SpaceWire interface should be designed to preclude damage while it is off and being actively driven by Payload. 

Note: Active voltage of 4.3V

X

 

 

 

3.5.2.1.1.4

Deleted

 

 

 

 

3.5.2.2

MPM Payload-Interface SpaceWire Quantity and Names

 

 

 

 

3.5.2.2.1.1

The MPM payload-interface should provide 12 SpaceWire ports. Note: See Figure 1.

 

X

 

 

3.5.2.3

MPM Payload-Interface SpaceWire Connector

 

 

 

 

3.5.2.3.1.1

Each MPM payload-interface SpaceWire unit connector should be a rectangular, 9-pin, M83513 (e.g., /04) connector.

 

X

 

 

3.5.2.4

MPM Payload-Interface SpaceWire Connector Pinout

 

 

 

 

3.5.2.4.1.1

Each MPM payload-interface SpaceWire unit connector should have the pinout specified in Table 1.

 

X

 

 

3.5.3

MPM Payload-Interface Discrete Signal Interface

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.1

MPM Payload-Interface Output Discrete Signal Quantity and Names

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.1.1.1

For each of its 12 payload interfaces, the MPM should provide four Discrete Signal outputs.

 

X

 

 

3.5.3.1.1.2

Each of the 12 MPM to payload Discrete Signals should be identified as follows.

Signal Name

(“N” used to simplify iterations 1-12)

[MPM & Payload signal base names are identical]

{payload “1” example: PL_IF_Port_Select_NL_01}

 

X

 

 

3.5.3.1.1.2.a

PL_IF_Port_Select_NL “N”

 

X

 

 

3.5.3.1.1.2.b

PL_Hard_Reset_NL “N”

 

X

 

 

3.5.3.1.1.2.c

PL_Soft_Reset_NL ”N”

 

X

 

 

3.5.3.1.1.2.d

PL_Time_Sync_NL ”N”

 

X

 

 

3.5.3.2

MPM Payload-Interface Input Discrete Signal Quantity and Names

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.2.1.1

The MPM should provide three Discrete Signal inputs per payload from a total of 12 payloads.

 

X

 

 

3.5.3.2.1.2

One of the three MPM input Discrete Signals per payload should be reserved for general purpose use. 

Note: If a payload is used to provide an alternate time sync signal, for example, the MPM input designated for general purpose use would be used to receive that time sync signal.

 

X

 

 

3.5.3.2.1.3

The MPM Discrete Signals inputs from the Payloads should be identified as follows:

 

X

 

 

 

Signal Name

(“N” used to simplify iterations 1-12)

[MPM & Payload signal base names are identical]

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.2.1.3.a

PL_Ready_NL “N”

 

X

 

 

3.5.3.2.1.3.b

PL_Fault “N”

 

X

 

 

3.5.3.2.1.3.c

PL General Purpose_NL ”N”

 

X

 

 

3.5.3.3

MPM Payload-Interface Discrete Signal Connector

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.3.1.1

The MPM Discrete Signal unit connector part number should be M24308/23-165 or equivalent.

 

X

 

 

3.5.3.4

MPM Payload-Interface Output and Input Discrete Signal Pinout

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.4.1.1

The MPM Discrete Signals interfacing with the Payloads should conform to the pinout specified in Appendix B Table 16.

 

X

 

 

3.5.3.5

MPM Payload-Interface Output Discrete Signal Characteristics

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.5.1

PL_IF_Port_Select_NL

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.5.1.1

To enable a specific payload C&DH interface port (i.e., 1-12) to actively communicate with the MPM, the MPM should apply a logic 0 to its PL_IF_Port_Select_NL output signal.

 

X

 

X

3.5.3.5.1.2

To disable a specific payload C&DH interface port (i.e., 1-12) from actively communicating with it, the MPM should apply a logic 1 to its respective PL_IF_Port_Select_NL output signal.

 

X

 

X

3.5.3.5.2

PL_Hard Reset_NL

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.5.2.1

To reset a specific payload’s C&DH interface (i.e., 1-12), the MPM should set the respective payloads PL_Hard_Reset_NL signal to logic 0 for at least 10 ms before returning that signal to a logic 1.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.5.3

PL_Soft Reset_NL

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.5.3.1

For an MPM to cause a specific payload C&DH interface (i.e., 1-12) to abort execution of its operating system, and enter into the Standby State, without removing power (primary or secondary) or resetting the payloads hardware functions, the MPM should apply a logic 0 to the respective payload’s PL_Soft_Reset_NL discrete for at least 10 ms and then apply a logic 1.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.5.4

PL_Time_Sync_NL

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.5.4.1

To notify a specific payload (i.e., 1-12) when a predefined time occurs, the MPM should apply a logic 0 pulse of 100 s to the respective payloads PL_Time_Sync_NL output.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.5.4.2

The MPM should use the falling edge of the PL_Time_Sync_NL signal to serve as the time of reference instance for synchronization.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.5.4.3

The assertion of MPM PL_Time_Sync_NL should have an accuracy of 25 ns or less relative to the falling edge of the clock used to maintain time within the MPM.

X

 

X

 

3.5.3.6

MPM Input (from Payloads) Discrete Signal Characteristics

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.6.1

PL_Ready_NL

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.6.1.1

The MPM should individually recognize each PL_Ready_NL input as valid after the input has been a logic 0 for 10 s.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.1.2

The MPM should not initiate command and data handling SpaceWire transactions with a Payload until that payload has asserted a valid PL_Ready_NL input to the MPM.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.2

PL_Fault

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.6.2.1

The MPM should individually recognize each PL_Fault input as valid after the input has been a logic 1 for 10 s.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.2.2

The state of each PL_Fault input should be registered and accessible by the MPM processor.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.2.3

A valid PL_Fault logic 1 should be capable of interrupting the MPM processor.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.3

Alt_Source_Time_Sync

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.6.3.1

When a payload provides an Alt_Source_Time_Sync across its PL_General_Purpose_NL discrete signal, the MPM should interpret the assertion of that signal as a transition from a logic 1 state to transition logic 0 state.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.3.2

When used as an Alt_Source_Time_Sync signal, the MPM should use the falling edge (logic 1 to logic 0 transition) of the PL_General_Purpose_NL signal to load a previously provided payload provided time value into Alt_Source_Time_Sync register.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.3.3

The Alt_Source_Time_Sync register should be composed of a 54-bit re-loadable register.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.3.4

The MPM Alt_Source_Time_Sync register clock should use a clock frequency of 40.92 MHz.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.3.5

The MPM should be able to read the PL_Time_clock register without interrupting the PL_Time_clock operation.

X

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.4

PL_General Purpose_NL

 

 

 

 

3.5.3.6.4.1

The state of each PL_General_Purpose_NL discrete signal should be registered and accessible by the MPM processor.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.4.2

The MPM should be able to select whether the PL_General_Purpose_NL input would set an MPM processor interrupt or be used to reload the Auxiliary_Payload_Time_Domain_Source_Time_Sync register.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.4.3

The MPM should interpret an event indication on each PL_General_Purpose_NL discrete signal as a transition from a logic 1 state to the logic 0 state.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.4.4

The MPM should be able to selectively route any one of the PL_General_Purpose_NL discrete signals for purposes of triggering the reload of an Alt_Source_Time_Sync counter.

X

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.4.5

When the PL_General_Purpose_NL signal is used to drive an MPM processor interrupt, a transition from logic 1 to 0 should set the MPM interrupt.

 

 

X

 

3.5.3.6.4.6

When the PL_General_Purpose_NL signal is used to reload the Auxiliary_Payload_Time_Domain_Register, a transition from logic 1 to 0 should load the register.

 

 

X

 

3.5.4

MPM Switch Payload-Interface

 

 

 

 

3.5.4.1

ETH Characteristics

 

 

 

 

3.5.4.1.1.1

The MPM Switch-portion should support ETH packet switching capabilities.

X

 

 

X

3.5.4.1.1.2

The transmit side of the Ethernet interfaces should comply with Section 54.6.3 of [IEEE 802.3-2018].

 

 

X

 

3.5.4.1.1.3

The receive side of the Ethernet interfaces should comply with Section 54.6.4 [IEEE 802.3-2018].

 

 

X

 

3.5.4.1.1.4

A free running pseudo-random bit-sequence per chapter 5.8 of [ITU-T-T O.150 with corrigendum May 2002] should be used for the testing of bit error rate compliance.

 

 

X

 

3.5.4.1.1.5

The MPM should provide an independent Bit Error Rate (BER) built in test (BIT) for each SERDES interface lane.

 

X

X

 

3.5.4.1.1.6

Each SERDES lane should support PRBS-31 in-situ BER testing.

 

 

X

 

3.5.4.1.1.7

Each MPM ETH interface should be designed to preclude damage while it is off and being actively driven by Payload.

Note: Active voltage of +/- 0.800 mV.

X

 

 

 

3.5.4.1.1.8

The MPM Switch-portion should be configurable by the Basic-portion via command.

 

 

X

 

3.5.4.1.1.9

The MPM should support configuring SERDES parametric via command.

 

X

X

 

3.5.4.2

ETH Quantity

 

 

 

 

3.5.4.2.1.1

Each MPM should provide twelve (12) non-redundant ETH Fat-Pipe ports, at least one for each (up to 12) Payload.

 

X

 

 

3.5.4.2.1.2

Each ETH Fat-Pipe port should have its own connector.

 

X

 

 

3.5.4.2.1.3

The last two digits of each ETH connector number should correspond to the ETH port number (e.g., ETH port 01 connector would be labeled J101 and port 12 would be labeled J112).

 

X

 

 

3.5.4.3

ETH Connector

 

 

 

 

3.5.4.3.1.1

Each MPM ETH unit connector part number should satisfy the connector attributes specified in Table 2.

 

X

 

 

3.5.4.4

ETH Pinout

 

 

 

 

3.5.4.4.1.1

Each MPM ETH unit connector should have the pinout specified in Table 3.

 

X

 

 

3.6

MPM to MPM Interface Requirements

 

 

 

 

3.6.1

MPM to MPM SpaceWire Interface

 

 

 

 

3.6.1.1

MPM to MPM SpaceWire Interface Characteristics

 

 

 

 

3.6.1.1.1.1

In support of the Hot-Hot configuration, the MPM A SpW_Hot port should interface with the MPM B SpW_Hot port.

 

X

 

 

3.6.1.1.1.2

When configured in a Hot-Hot redundancy configuration, the Active MPM Hot-Hot SpareWire interface should be initialized for AutoStart.

 

 

X

 

3.6.1.1.1.3

When configured in a Hot-Hot redundancy configuration, the Monitor MPM Hot-Hot SpareWire interface should be initialized for LinkStart.

 

 

X

 

3.6.1.1.1.4

In the Hot-Hot configuration, after initialization, each MPM SpaceWire receive and transmit interface to the other MPM should independently support a maximum  data rate of 200 Mbps.

X

 

X

 

3.6.1.2

MPM to MPM SpaceWire Quantity and Names

 

 

 

 

3.6.1.2.1.1

Each MPM should provide a SpaceWire port dedicated for use only when the MPMs are configured for a Hot-Hot configuration.

 

X

 

 

3.6.1.2.1.2

In support of the Hot-Hot configurations, the SpaceWire port used to communicate with the other MPM should be identified as SpW_Hot.

 

X

 

 

3.6.1.3

MPM to MPM SpaceWire Connector

 

 

 

 

3.6.1.3.1.1

The MPM SpaceWire unit connector part number should be a rectangular, 9-pin, M83513 (e.g., /04 or /19) connector.

 

X

 

 

3.6.1.4

MPM to MPM SpaceWire Pinout

 

 

 

 

3.6.1.4.1.1

The MPM-to-MPM SpaceWire unit connector should have the pinout specified in Table 1.

 

X

 

 

3.6.2

MPM to MPM Discrete Signals

 

 

 

 

3.6.2.1

MPM to MPM Discrete Signal (Output) Interface Characteristics

 

 

 

 

3.6.2.1.1.1

When an MPM is commanded by the Host System to enter into Monitor Mode, it should set the MPM_Active_Out_NL discrete to logic 1.

 

X

 

X

3.6.2.1.1.2

When an MPM is commanded by the Host System to enter into Active Mode, it should set the MPM_Active_Out_NL discrete to logic 0.

 

X

 

X

3.6.2.1.1.3

When an MPM in the Active Mode detects that its watchdog timer timed-out or the MPM detects a multi-bit memory error it should set the MPM_Active_Out_NL discrete to logic 1.

 

X

 

X

3.6.2.1.1.4

When an MPM is in the Monitor Mode and it detects that the other MPM has set its MPM_Active_Out_NL discrete to logic 1, the MPM that is currently in Monitor Mode should transition to Active Mode and perform the Active Mode function (including assuming payload interface management control) within 500 milliseconds, unless otherwise specified by the mission requirements.

 

X

 

X

3.6.2.1.1.5

When in the Hot-Hot configuration, to notify the Monitor MPM when a predefined time (transported via MPM to MPM SpareWire interface) occurs, the Active MPM should assert its Active_Time_Sync_Out_NL  discrete with a logic 0 for at least 100 microseconds then de-assert it with a logic 1.

 

X

 

X

3.6.2.1.1.6

The falling edge (logic 1 to 0 transition) of the Active MPM’s Active_Time_Sync_Out_NL should occur within 25 ns of the predefined time.

 

X

 

X

3.6.2.2

MPM to MPM Discrete Signal (Output) Quantity and Names

 

 

 

 

3.6.2.2.1.1

The HOT-HOT Discrete Signal output of each MPM should be identified and connected as follows:

Note: The MPM to MPM Discrete Signal output and input signals use the same connector.

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.2.1.1.a

Signal Name: Gnd

MPM Connector: M24308/23-119

Pin #: 1

Polarity:

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.2.1.1.b

Signal Name: MPM_Active_NL_P_O

MPM Connector: M24308/23-119

Pin #: 2

Polarity: P

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.2.1.1.c

Signal Name: MPM_Active_NL_N_O

MPM Connector: M24308/23-119

Pin #: 3

Polarity: N

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.2.1.1.d

Signal Name: Active_Time_Sync_NL_P_O

MPM Connector: M24308/23-119

Pin #: 10

Polarity: P

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.2.1.1.e

Signal Name: Active_Time_Sync_NL_N_O

MPM Connector: M24308/23-119

Pin #: 11

Polarity: N

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.3

MPM to MPM Discrete Signal (Input) Quantity and Names

 

 

 

 

3.6.2.3.1.1

The HOT-HOT Discrete Signal input of each MPM should be identified and connected as follows:

Note: The MPM to MPM Discrete Signal output and input signals use the same connector.

 

 

 

 

3.6.2.3.1.1.a

Signal name: MPM_Active_NL_P_I

Connector (M24308/23-119) pin #:  4

Signal polarity: P

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.3.1.1.b

Signal name: MPM_Active_NL_N_I

Connector (M24308/23-119) pin #:  5

Signal polarity: N

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.3.1.1.c

Signal name: Gnd

Connector (M24308/23-119) pin #:  8, 9, 15

Signal polarity:

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.3.1.1.d

Signal name: Active Time Sync_NL_P_I

Connector (M24308/23-119) pin #:  12

Signal polarity: P

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.3.1.1.e

Signal name: Active Time Sync_ NL_P_I

Connector (M24308/23-119) pin #:  13

Signal polarity: N

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.3.1.2

When in a HOT-HOT configuration, a logic 0 read from the MPM_Active_In_NL signal interface should be interpreted as the other MPM to be in the Active Mode.

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.3.1.3

When in a HOT-HOT configuration, a logic 1 read from the MPM_Active_In_NL signal interface should be interpreted as the other MPM to be in the Monitor Mode.

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.3.1.4

When in a HOT-HOT configuration, the falling edge of the Active_Time_Sync_In_NL should indicate when a previously provided time has occurred.  Note: That edge is intended to indicate when a previously provided time value is to be loaded into an MPM internal time counter register.

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.4

MPM to MPM Discrete Signal Connector

 

 

 

 

3.6.2.4.1.1

The unit connector part number for the Discrete signals’ MPM_Active_In and MPM_Active_Out should be M24308/23-20.

 

X

 

 

3.6.2.5

3.7

MPM Internal Basic/Switch Interface Requirements

 

 

 

 

3.7.1

Basic/Switch Bidirectional Serial-Communication Interface

 

 

 

 

3.7.1.1.1.1

The MPM Basic-portion and Switch-portion should each provide a single shared SpaceWire port reserved for communication between each portion.

 

X

 

 

3.7.1.1.1.2

The Spacewire signaling between the Basic-portion and the Switch-portion should be double-clocked. 

Note: This signaling would be used only to transport Switch commands, Switch controls, and Switch status signaling between the Basic-portion and the Switch-portion of the MPM: it would not be used to transport any information being routed through  a Switch.

X

X

 

 

3.7.1.1.1.3

The implementation of the Spacewire signaling (i.e., signal double clocking within MPM portions) should be approved by the NSA.

 

X

 

 

3.7.1.1.1.4

The routing of the Spacewire wiring between the Basic and Switch-portions should be approved by the NSA.

 

X

 

 

3.7.2

Basic-portion to Switch-portion Discrete Signaling Interface

 

 

 

 

3.7.2.1.1.1

Each discrete signal from the Basic-portion to the Switch-portion should be double clocked (two latching buffers in a series configuration).

 

X

 

 

3.7.2.1.1.2

The MPM Basic to Switch interface should include the following four (4) discrete LVDS signals:

 

 

 

 

3.7.2.1.1.2.a

Switch-portion_Processor_Hard_Reset_NL

 

X

 

 

3.7.2.1.1.2.b

Switch-portion_Processor_Soft_Reset_NL

 

X

 

 

3.7.2.1.1.2.c

Switch_Device_Reset_NL

 

X

 

 

3.7.2.1.1.2.d

Basic-portion_Fault_NL

 

X

 

 

3.7.2.1.1.3

The implementation of the LVDS signaling (e.g., double clocking within portions) should be approved by the NSA.

 

X

 

 

3.7.2.1.1.4

The routing of the LVDS wiring between the Basic- and Switch-portions should be approved by the NSA.

 

X

 

 

3.7.2.1.1.5

The Basic-portion assertion (logic 0) of the Switch-portion_Processor_Hard_Reset_NL interface signal for a minimum duration equivalent to 255 periods of the Switch processor clock followed by de-assertion should cause the Switch-portion processor to perform a hard-reset.

Note: The 255 cycles of logic “0” assertion are needed to reset Switch circuitry and allow the Switch phase-lock-loop to achieve lock.

 

 

X

 

3.7.2.1.1.6

The assertion of the Switch-portion_Hard_Reset_NL signal should cause the Switch-portion processor to vector to its Hard Reset Starting Address. 

Note: The Hard Reset Starting Address value would be defined by specification for the processor implemented within the Switch-portion.

 

 

X

 

3.7.2.1.1.7

The Basic-portion assertion (logic 0) of the Switch-portion_Processor_Soft_Reset_NL interface signal for the equivalent of at least two (2) Switch processor clock cycles followed by de-assertion should cause the Switch-portion’s processor to perform a soft-reset.

 

 

X

 

3.7.2.1.1.8

The Basic-portion assertion (logic 0) of the Switch_Device_Reset_NL interface signal for a minimum duration of 10 milli-seconds before de-assertion should cause the Switch-device to perform a reset.

 

 

X

 

3.7.2.1.1.9

When power is applied, the Basic-portion’s Basic-portion_Fault_NL signal should initialize to logic “1”.

 

 

X

 

3.7.2.1.1.10

When the Basic-portion Processor detects a critical processing fault (e.g., multi-bit error, software time-out/fault) it’s Basic-portion_Fault_NL at the Basic/Switch interface should be logic “0”.

 

 

X

 

3.7.3

Switch-portion to Basic-portion Discrete Signaling Interface

 

 

 

 

3.7.3.1.1.1

Each discrete signal from the Switch-portion to the Basic-portion should be double clocked (two latched buffers in a series configuration).

 

X

 

 

3.7.3.1.1.2

The MPM Switch to Basic interface should include the following five (5) discrete LVDS signals:

 

X

 

 

3.7.3.1.1.2.a

Switch_ Portion_ON_NL

 

X

 

 

3.7.3.1.1.2.b

Switch_Ready_NL

 

X

 

 

3.7.3.1.1.2.c

Switch_Fault

 

X

 

 

3.7.3.1.1.2.d

Processor_Ready_NL

 

X

 

 

3.7.3.1.1.2.e

Processor_Fault

 

X

 

 

3.7.3.1.1.3

The implementation of the LVDS signaling (e.g., signal double clocking within portions) should be approved by the NSA.

 

X

 

 

3.7.3.1.1.4

The routing of the LVDS wiring between the Basic- and Switch-portions should be approved by the NSA.

 

X

 

 

3.7.3.2

Switch_ Portion_ON_NL

 

 

 

 

3.7.3.2.1.1

During initial application of primary input power to the Switch-portion, the Switch-portion to Basic-portion interface signal entitled Switch_ Portion_ON_NL  should be a logic 1.

 

 

X

 

3.7.3.2.1.2

When the Switch-portion Switch successfully completes its initialization and the Processor completes its software initialization, the Switch_ Portion_ON_NL signal should be logic 0.

Note: Once the Switch-portion has completed its hardware and software initialization, it would be ready for its application initialization.  Application information transfers would occur over the SpaceWire interface between the Basic- and Switch-portions.  Those transactions would likely need to be reviewed by the NSA.

 

 

X

 

3.7.3.3

Switch_Ready_NL

 

 

 

 

3.7.3.3.1.1

During initial application of primary input power to the Switch-portion, the Switch-portion to Basic-portion interface signal entitled Switch_Ready_NL should be a logic 1.

X

 

X

 

3.7.3.3.1.2

After the Switch-portion Switch has successfully completed its hardware initialization, the Switch_Ready_NL signal should be logic 0.

X

 

X

 

3.7.3.

Processor_Ready_NL

 

 

 

 

3.7.3..1.1

During initial application of primary input power to the Switch-portion, the Switch-portion to Basic-portion interface signal entitled Processor_Ready_NL should be a logic 1.

X

 

X

 

3.7.3..1.2

After the Switch-portion Processor has successfully completed its hardware initialization, the Processor_Ready_NL signal should be logic 0.

X

 

X

 

3.7.3.5

Switch_Fault

 

 

 

 

3.7.3.5.1.1

After the Switch-portion Switch has successfully completed hardware initialization, and the Switch has no faults, the Switch_Fault signal should be logic 0.

X

 

X

 

3.7.3.5.1.2

When the Switch-portion Switch detects a fault, the Switch_Fault signal should be logic 1.

X

 

X

 

3.7.3.6

Processor_Fault

 

 

 

 

3.7.3.6.1.1

After the Switch-portion Processor has successfully completed its hardware initialization, and the Processor has no faults, the Processor_Fault signal should be logic 0.

X

 

X

 

3.7.3.6.1.2

When the Switch-portion Processor detects a fault condition that is not autonomously correctable, it should set the Processor_Fault to logic 1 within 100 micro-seconds.

X

 

X

 

3.8

MPM States and Modes

 

 

 

 

3.8.1

Power On and Off

 

 

 

 

3.8.1.1.1.1

The MPM Basic-portion and Switch-portion should have independent power inputs.  Note: The purpose of using independent power inputs is to enable the MPM to operate in a low power Mode when necessary (i.e., when the satellite is in a low power Mode [e.g., safe Mode]).

 

X

 

 

3.8.1.1.1.2

The Switch-portion should not be ON when the Basic-portion is OFF.

 

X

 

 

3.8.1.1.1.3

Upon initial application of power to the MPM Basic-portion, it should enter Standby State.

 

 

X

 

3.8.1.1.1.4

After initial application of power, the MPM should enter Idle Mode.

 

 

X

 

3.8.1.1.1.5

When power is applied to the Basic-portion and the Switch-portion, the MPM should enter Operational State.

 

 

X

 

3.8.2

States and Modes

 

 

 

 

3.8.2.1

States

 

 

 

 

3.8.2.1.1.1

An MPM should be in a Standby State when its Basic-portion is powered on and its Switch-portion is off. Note: See  Figure 10 (MPM States and Modes).

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.1.1.2

An MPM should be in an Operational State when its Basic-portion and Switch-portion have powered applied to them.

Note: See  Figure 10 (MPM States and Modes).

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.2

Modes

 

 

 

 

3.8.2.2.1.1

The MPM should enter into a valid Mode when commanded via its Host System interface (i.e., SpaceWire) to enter that Mode. Note: See Figure 10 (MPM States and Modes).

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.2.1.2

When commanded via its Host System interface (i.e., SpaceWire) to reset the Switch-portion of an MPM, the MPM Basic should command the Switch-portion to perform a hard reset.

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.2.1.3

When commanded by the Host System (via SpaceWire) to reinitialize the Switch-portion flight software, the MPM Basic should command the Switch-portion to perform a soft reset.

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.3

Standby State and Modes

 

 

 

 

3.8.2.3.1.1

When an MPM initially enters the Standby State, it should enter Idle Mode.

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.3.1.2

In the Standby State, an MPM should have only three Modes: Idle, Basic, and Diagnostic.

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.3.1.3

In Standby State, all Mode changes should be commanded by the Host System. Note: A command may be sent to set a logic value in non-volatile MPM memory that if checked after an MPM entered Idle Mode would authorize that MPM to autonomously enter another valid Mode, such as Basic.

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.3.1.4

An MPM should be capable of transitioning to the Standby State under the following conditions:

 

 

 

 

3.8.2.3.1.4.a.

From a power off condition after power is supplied to the Basic-portion only and receipt of a power-on command discrete from the Host System.

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.3.1.4.b.

When power is not applied to the Switch-portion.

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.3.1.5

In the Standby State and Idle Mode, the following MPM functionality should be enabled:

 

 

 

 

3.8.2.3.1.5.a

Communication with the Host System via SpaceWire

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.3.1.5.b

All discrete signals with the Host System

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.3.1.5.c

When configured in a HOT-HOT configuration, all discrete signals with the other MPM

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.3.1.5.d

When configured in a HOT-HOT configuration, communication with the other MPM over the SpW_Hot SpaceWire interface

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.3.1.5.e

All discrete signals with the payloads

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.3.1.6

In the Standby State and Basic Mode, the following MPM functionality should be enabled:

 

 

 

 

3.8.2.3.1.6.a

Communication with the Host System via SpaceWire

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.3.1.6.b

All discrete signals with the Host System

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.3.1.6.c

When configured in a HOT-HOT configuration, all discrete signals with the other MPM

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.3.1.6.d

When configured in a HOT-HOT configuration, communication with the other MPM over the SpW_Hot SpaceWire interface

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.3.1.6.e

All discrete signals with the payloads

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.3.1.6.f

Communication with the payloads via SpaceWire

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.3.1.7

The MPM should use the Standby State, Diagnostic Mode to communicate with the Host System to diagnose and possibly resolve a problem with the MPM. 

Note: Depending upon the problem, the MPM may be able to perform C&DH functions with Host System and the one or more payload.

 

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.4

Operational State and Mode

 

 

 

 

3.8.2.4.1.1

The MPM should be in the Standby State and Basic Mode before transitioning to the Operational State. Note: When the transition to the Operational State occurs, the MPM would be in its Basic Mode.

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.4.1.2

In the Operational State, a normally operating MPM should be able to achieve the following Modes:

 

 

 

 

3.8.2.4.1.2.a

Idle

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.4.1.2.b

Basic

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.4.1.2.c

Active Mode

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.4.1.2.d

Diagnostic Mode

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.4.1.2.e

Monitor Mode (only applicable when MPMs are configured in a Hot-Hot configuration)

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.4.1.3

Unless it is the direct result of an autonomous fault management action, the MPM should only change Modes upon the receipt of a SpaceWire command to do so from the Host System.

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.4.1.4

The MPM should complete Switch-portion initialization before entering into Active Mode.

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.4.1.5

The MPM should support mission data switching while in the Active Mode and Diagnostic Mode.

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.4.1.6

The MPM should not switch mission data while in the Idle, Basic or Monitor Mode.  Note: The switching of mission data while the MPM is in Diagnostic Mode is not recommended but may be feasible depending upon the reason(s) for being in Diagnostic Mode.

 

X

 

 

3.8.2.4.1.7

When two MPMs are functioning properly in a Hot-Hot configuration, one MPM should be in the Operational State and Active Mode while the other is in the Operational State and Monitor Mode. Note: If an MPM is designed as a single-thread unit, this requirement may not be testable at the unit level; however, it would be testable if the test equipment emulated the “other” MPM or if the MPM was designed as a dual-thread unit.

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.4.1.8

While operating in the Hot-Hot configuration, the MPM currently in Monitor Mode should receive from the MPM in Active Mode all of the Host System and payload state and telemetry information necessary for the Monitor Mode MPM to, upon detection of a fault in the Active Mode MPM, subsume the role of an Active MPM within the transition period (e.g., 1 second) required by the mission.

X

 

X

 

3.8.2.4.1.9

While operating in the Hot-Hot configuration, the MPM currently in Active Mode should set and maintain its MPM Active OUT discrete to a logic 0 until it detects an internal fault (e.g., watchdog timeout, double-bit memory error).

X

 

X

 

3.8.2.4.1.10

While operating in the Hot-Hot configuration, when the Active Mode MPM detects an internal fault warranting setting its MPM Active OUT discrete to logic 1, it should within 1 ms - set its MPM_Fault discrete signals to the Host System to logic 1.

X

 

X

 

3.8.2.4.1.11

While operating in the Hot-Hot configuration, when the Monitor MPM detects a logic 1 from its MPM Active IN discrete, it should immediately set its MPM Active OUT discrete to a logic 0 until it detects an internal fault (e.g., watchdog timeout, double-bit memory error).

X

 

X

 

3.8.2.4.1.12

When two MPMs are functioning properly in a Hot-Warm configuration, one MPM should be in the Operational State and Active Mode while the other is in the Standby State and Idle Mode.

 

 

X

 

3.8.2.4.1.13

When in a Hot-Cold configuration, one MPM should be powered off while the other is in a valid state and Mode.

 

X

 

 

3.9

MPM Timekeeping

 

 

 

 

3.9.1

Clocks and Timers

 

 

 

 

3.9.1.1

MPM Watchdog Timer

 

 

 

 

3.9.1.1.1.1

The MPM should contain a watchdog timer operated with a clock frequency of 40.92 MHz (+/- 0.025 ppm).

X

 

X

 

3.9.1.1.1.2

The MPM watchdog timer should accommodate maximum count duration of 2 seconds.

X

 

X

 

3.9.1.1.1.3

The MPM watchdog timer timeout count should be programmable via command.

 

 

X

 

3.9.1.1.1.4

The MPM should generate a maskable interrupt when the watchdog timer reaches the maximum timeout count.

 

 

X

 

3.9.1.2

MPM Timekeeping Clock

 

 

 

 

3.9.1.2.1.1

The MPM should contain a timekeeping clock operated with a clock frequency of 40.92 MHz (+/- 0.025 ppm) and a maximum clock time of no less than 10 years.

X

 

 

 

3.9.1.2.1.2

The MPM timekeeping clock should be settable periodically via command.

 

X

 

 

3.9.1.2.1.3

The MPM timekeeping clock should be reset via command.

 

 

X

 

3.9.1.2.1.4

The MPM timekeeping clock should rollover to 0 when it reaches the maximum clock time of 10 years.

X

 

 

 

3.9.1.3

MPM Auxiliary Timer

 

 

 

 

3.9.1.3.1.1

The MPM should contain an auxiliary timer operated with a clock frequency of 40.92 MHz (+/- 0.025 ppm).

X

 

 

 

3.9.1.3.1.2

The MPM auxiliary timer should accommodate a maximum count duration of 2 seconds.

X

 

 

 

3.9.1.3.1.3

The MPM auxiliary timer timeout count should be programmable via command.

 

 

X

 

3.9.1.3.1.4

The MPM should generate a maskable interrupt when the auxiliary timer reaches the maximum timeout count.

 

 

X

 

3.9.1.4

Host System Domain Time Counter

 

 

 

 

3.9.1.4.1.1

The MPM Host System Domain Time Counter should use a clock frequency of 40.92 MHz (+/- 0.025 ppm).

X

 

 

 

3.9.1.4.1.2

The MPM should include a 54-bit Host System Domain Time Counter load register.

 

X

 

 

3.9.1.4.1.3

The MPM should include a 54-bit Host System Domain Time Counter loadable by the Host System Domain Time Counter load register.

 

X

X

 

3.9.1.4.1.4

The MPM 54-bit Host System Domain Time Counter load register should be able to load its value into a 54-bit Host System Domain Time Counter within 25 ns when enabled by the MPM and at the assertion of the HS_Time_Sync_NL signal.

X

 

X

 

3.9.1.4.1.5

The MPM should include a 54-bit Host System Domain Time Counter read register.

 

X

 

 

3.9.1.4.1.6

The MPM Host System Domain Time Counter should be loadable and readable by the MPM processor.

 

 

X

 

3.9.1.4.1.7

The Host System Domain Time Counter 54-bit register should interface with a re-programmable 54-bit comparator.

 

X

 

 

3.9.1.4.1.8

The MPM processor should be able to load a 54-bit comparison value into the 54-bit Host System Domain Time Counter comparator.

 

X

X

 

3.9.1.4.1.9

The 54-bit comparator should have an output signal routable, when enabled, to individually and also collectively drive any MPM processor selected combination of  PL_Time_Sync_NL signals.

 

X

X

 

3.9.1.5

 Auxiliary Payload Time Counter

 

 

 

 

3.9.1.5.1.1

The MPM PL  Time Clock counter should use a clock frequency of 40.92 MHz (+/- 0.025 ppm).

X

 

 

 

3.9.1.5.1.2

The MPM should include a 54-bit Auxiliary Payload Time Counter load register.

 

X

 

 

3.9.1.5.1.3

The MPM should include a 54-bit Auxiliary Payload Time Counter loadable by the PL Time Clock load register.

 

X

X

 

3.9.1.5.1.4

The MPM 54-bit Auxiliary Payload Time Counter load register should be able to load its value into a 54-bit PL Time Clock Counter when enabled by the MPM and at the assertion of the PL_Time_Sync_NL signal.

 

X

X

 

3.9.1.5.1.5

The MPM should include a 54-bit Auxiliary Payload Time Counter read register.

 

X

 

 

3.9.1.5.1.6

The MPM Auxiliary Payload Time Counter should be loadable and readable by the MPM processor.

 

 

X

 

3.9.1.5.1.7

The Auxiliary Payload Time Counter 54-bit register should interface with a re-programmable 54-bit comparator.

 

X

 

 

3.9.1.5.1.8

The MPM processor should be able to load a 54-bit comparison value into the 54-bit Payload Time Counter comparator.

 

X

X

 

3.9.1.5.1.9

The 54-bit comparator should have an output signal routable, when enabled by the MPM, to individually and also collectively drive any MPM processor selected combination of  PL_Time_Sync_NL signals.

 

X

X

 

3.9.1.5.1.10

The 54-bit comparator should have an output signal that, when enabled by the MPM, asserts the Aux_Time_Sync_NL discrete to the Host System Subsystem.

 

X

X

 

3.10

MPM Computation Resources

 

 

 

 

3.10.1

Computational Throughput Capacity

 

 

 

 

3.10.1.1.1.1

The MPM Basic-portion should provide no less than 3.514E6 Dhrystones per second (2000 MIPS).

Note: In addition to command and data handling functions, this processing capability includes significant computational throughput capacity reserve for planned but not yet solidified cyber functions that would need to be completed within short periods of time.

X

 

X

 

3.10.1.1.1.2

The MPM Switch-portion should provide no less than 3.514E6 Dhrystones per second (2000 MIPS).

Note: In addition to controlling Switch functions and communicating with the Basic-portion, this capability includes significant computational throughput capacity reserve for planned but not yet solidified cyber functions that would need to be completed within short periods of time.

X

 

X

 

3.10.2

Memory Capacity

 

 

 

 

3.10.2.1.1.1

The MPM Basic-portion should provide no less than 4 GBytes of volatile memory.

 

X

 

 

3.10.2.1.1.2

The MPM Basic-portion should provide no less than 1 GBytes of non-volatile memory.

 

X

 

 

3.10.2.1.1.3

The MPM Switch-portion should provide no less than 1 GBytes of volatile memory.

 

X

 

 

3.10.2.1.1.4

The MPM Switch-portion should provide no less than 1 GBytes of non-volatile memory.

 

X

 

 

3.11

MPM Unit Equipment Fault-Management Considerations

 

 

 

 

3.11.1

MPM Redundancy

 

 

 

 

3.11.1.1

MPM Redundancy Configurations

 

 

 

 

3.11.1.1.1.1

The MPM should support the following redundancy configurations:

 

 

 

 

3.11.1.1.1.1.a

Hot-Cold

 

 

X

 

3.11.1.1.1.1.b

Hot-Warm

 

 

X

 

3.11.1.1.1.1.c

Hot-Hot

 

 

X

 

3.11.2

MPM Power-Fault

 

 

 

 

3.11.2.1

Power-Fault Recovery

 

 

 

 

3.11.2.1.1.1

The MPM should survive sudden unplanned loss of main power; and, upon reapplication of power, boot up into the Idle Mode.

X

 

 

 

3.11.3

MPM Basic-portion Fault

 

 

 

 

3.11.3.1

MPM-Basic Internal Fault Detection Features

 

 

 

 

3.11.3.1.1.1

The MPM should allow verification of each of its following interrupt functions:

 

 

 

 

3.11.3.1.1.1.a

Interrupt generation

 

 

X

 

3.11.3.1.1.1.b

Interrupt masking

 

 

X

 

3.11.3.1.1.1.c

Interrupt status (e.g., Memory Fault, Switch_Fault Timer timeout)

 

 

X

 

3.11.3.1.1.2

The MPM should allow individual errors to be forced into each EDAC check bit.

 

 

X

 

3.11.3.1.1.3

The MPM should report all detected correctable memory errors and, when available, the following:

X

 

X

 

3.11.3.1.1.3.a

Address of the memory error

 

 

X

 

3.11.3.1.1.3.b

Information defining which bit(s) were erroneous

 

 

X

 

3.11.3.1.1.3.c

Source of the memory Host System transaction

 

 

X

 

3.11.3.2

Switch-portion Activity

 

 

 

 

3.11.3.2.1.1

When the MPM Switch-portion detects that the Basic-portion reports a Fault or reports that it is not Ready, the Switch-portion switching functions should be disabled.

 

 

X

 

3.12

MPM Reliability

 

 

 

 

3.12.1

Failure Rates and Calculations

 

 

 

 

3.12.1.1.1.1

The MPM, as a single-thread unit operating over an 8 year mission, should have a probability of success of 0.7044 (or greater) over the operating life based on the performance criteria, environments, 100% duty cycle, and design considerations in this specification.

Note : A dual-redundant unit using standby redundancy should have a probability of 0.9499 or greater and a dual-redundant unit using active redundancy should have a probability of 0.9126 or greater.

X

 

 

 

3.12.1.1.1.2

The unit design should use failure rates based upon a mission average baseplate temperature of 55 deg C.

 

X

 

 

3.12.1.1.1.3

Reliability calculations should be based on part failure rate data from MIL-HDBK-217F or life test data.

 

X

 

 

3.12.2

Operating Life

 

 

 

 

3.12.2.1.1.1

The MPM should be designed for an on-orbit operating life of 8 years minimum.

X

 

 

 

3.12.3

Ground Integration

 

 

 

 

3.12.3.1.1.1

The MPM should be designed for a ground integration and test environment for a period of up to six years.

X

 

 

 

3.12.4

Storage Life

 

 

 

 

3.12.4.1.1.1

The MPM should withstand storage for up to 7 years in an environment defined in table below.

X

 

 

 

3.12.4.1.1.1.a

Environment: Thermal

Value: Ambient (68 F to 75F)

 

X

 

 

3.12.4.1.1.1.b

Environment: Pressure

Value: Atmospheric pressure

 

X

 

 

3.12.4.1.1.1.c

Environment: Relative Humidity

Value: 40% to 50%

 

X

 

 

3.12.5

Redundancy

 

 

 

 

3.12.5.1.1.1

The MPM should have separate driver and receiver devices for all A/B signal pairs.

 

X

X

 

3.13

Environmental Requirements

 

 

 

 

3.13.1

Survivability

 

 

 

 

3.13.1.1

Overview

 

 

 

 

3.13.1.2

Radiation Environments

 

 

 

 

3.13.1.2.1

Total Ionizing Dose and Displacement Damage Fluence

 

 

 

 

3.13.1.2.2

Environments for Single-Event Effects

 

 

 

 

3.13.1.2.2.1

For background galactic cosmic rays (GCRs), the GEO environment, as specified by CREME96, should be used with 100 mils of Al shielding for all orbits.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.2.2.2

For solar particle events (SPE), one worst week at GEO, as specified by CREME96, should be used with 100 mils of Al shielding for all orbits.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.2.2.3

For background and solar protons, the environments specified by CREME96 for the above GCR and SPE conditions for GEO should be used for all orbits.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.2.2.4

For missions with more stringent trapped proton environments than GPS (environment reference only), the MPM should be designed to meet those more restrictive requirements for specified orbits.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.2.2.5

CREME96 should be used with 100 mils of Al shielding to determine the environment and event rates for electronic devices that are sensitive to trapped proton induced SEE.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.2.3

Manmade Threat Environment

 

 

 

 

3.13.1.2.3.1

If an MPM is required to operate in a manmade environment, the manmade radiation threat environment specified in [MIL-STD-3053] (Satellite Systems Natural and Nuclear Environment Standard) should be used.

 

X

 

 

3.13.1.2.3.2

If the manmade threat environment is not given in [MIL-STD-3053] for a specified orbit, then the manmade environment for the worst-case orbit in [MIL-STD-3053] should be assumed, unless otherwise directed by the sponsoring agency.

 

X

 

 

3.13.1.3

Radiation Requirements

 

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.1

Requirements for Total Ionizing Dose and Displacement Damage Effects

 

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.1.1

Electronic devices used in the MPM should meet all performance requirements with a probability of 0.9999 at a confidence level of 90%, based on small-sample statistics, when exposed to the total ionizing dose and 1-MeV-equivalent neutron fluence received during the mission by parts for their specific shielding configurations, unless directed otherwise by the sponsoring agency.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.1.2

Radiation exposure levels presented in Table 8 should be used for this purpose with no additional radiation design margin (RDM) applied (i.e., RDM = 1).

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.1.3

All electronic devices used in the MPM should meet performance requirements after exposure to at least 1X the TID plus at least 1X the displacement damage exposure levels given in Table 8.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.2

Requirements for Single-Event Effects

 

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.2.1

The follow types of single-event effects should be accounted for in meeting requirements: single-event upset (SEU), single-event transients (SETs), single-event functional interrupt (SEFI), single-event latch-up (SEL), single-event burnout (SEB), single-event gate rupture (SEGR), single-event dielectric rupture (SEDR), and single-event hard errors (SHE) (also referred to as stuck bits).

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.2.2

Electronic devices that exhibit destructive single-event effects at a threshold LET (linear energy transfer) 37 MeV-cm2/mg should not be used.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.2.3

Electronic devices that exhibit destructive single-event effects at a threshold LET > 75 MeV-cm2/mg should be acceptable for use as-is.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.2.4

Electronic devices that exhibit destructive single-event effects at a threshold LET in the range from > 37 to 75 MeV-cm2/mg should not be used unless it is demonstrated that the failure rate for a specific device can be accommodated within the reliability budget for the unit. For such assessments, destructive SEEs can be treated as random failures.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.2.5

Electronic devices that exhibit nondestructive SEL at a LET 75 MeV-cm2/mg should be reported to the program.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.2.6

Electronic devices that exhibit nondestructive SEL at a LET 75 MeV-cm2/mg that are reported to the program should be evaluated for use on a case-by-case basis.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.2.7

Electronic devices that exhibit nondestructive SEL at a LET 75 MeV-cm2/mg and are reported for potential use by the program should have an appropriate SEL mitigation procedure identified as part of that evaluation.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.2.8

Electronic parts should be selected to minimize errors due to SEUs, SETs, and SEFIs.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.2.9

The unit using the selected parts should comply with its program SEE rate allocation with respect to event rates requiring external intervention for recovery.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.2.10

For nondestructive SEEs in electronic devices that require ground intervention for recovery, the MPM should exhibit an overall rate of less than or equal to 0.1 event/year.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.2.11

FPGAs and ASICs should implement SEE mitigation techniques (e.g., EDAC, memory scrubbing, and TMR) when needed to meet program ground intervention requirements.

 

X

 

 

3.13.1.3.2.12

Discrete high-voltage power transistors, including MOS and bipolar devices, that are susceptible to SEB, SEGR, or SEDR should maintain operating voltages 75% of their respective SEE safe operating areas based on information in manufacturers’ datasheets.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.3

Requirements for Manmade Radiation Environment Effects

 

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.3.1

The manmade radiation threat requirements specified in [MIL-STD-3053] (Satellite Systems Natural and Nuclear Environment Standard) should be used.

 

X

 

 

3.13.1.3.3.2

If the mission radiation survivability requirements are not given in [MIL-STD-3053] for a specified orbit, the requirements for the worst-case orbit in [MIL-STD-3053] should be assumed unless otherwise directed by the sponsoring agency.

 

X

 

 

3.13.1.3.3.3

The MPM should be designed to be hardened against derived SGEMP levels based on the manmade environments given in [MIL-STD-3053].

 

X

 

 

3.13.1.3.4

Electrostatic Discharge Control

 

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.4.1

The MPM should have no more than 0.01-cm2 surface area of ungrounded metal within 100 mils of an electrostatic discharge (ESD) sensitive part.

Note: Ungrounded is defined as there being greater than 10-M of resistance between the floating metal and the chassis electrical ground or electrical power return.

 

X

 

 

3.13.1.3.4.2

The MPM should have no more than 0.2-cm2 of surface area for ungrounded metal greater than 100 mils from an electrostatic discharge sensitive part.

Note 1: Ungrounded is defined as there being greater than 10-M of resistance between the floating metal and the chassis electrical ground or electrical power return.

Note 2: This floating metal requirement does not prevent electrostatic discharges.  It reduces the size of the electrostatic discharges to 0.7 ìJ, and the energy is dependent on the dielectric constant, thickness, and breakdown strength

 

X

 

 

3.13.1.3.4.3

All radiation spot shields, on parts inside the MPM, should be grounded.

 

X

 

 

3.13.1.3.4.4

The MPM should survive all discharges from deep dielectric charging

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.4.5

An electrostatic discharge control program meeting the requirements of ANSI/ESDA 20.20 or equivalent should be maintained for all parts, units, and assemblies during acquisition, storage, assembly, integration, and test.

 

X

 

 

3.13.1.3.4.6

The MPM should be designed so that the electron flux normally incident on ungrounded metals and/or insulators is 0.1 pA/ cm2 (6.25E5 electrons/cm2/s); or, the minimum shielding provided by the MPM housing and the spacecraft structure (if the equipment is located wholly within the spacecraft structure) is equal to or greater than 120 mil of equivalent aluminum.

Note: This does not prevent all electrostatic discharges from floating metal but does reduce it to a small rate.  These electrostatic discharges still may upset the circuits that are not designed to operate through these electrostatic discharges. 

X

X

3.13.1.3.4.8

Electrical interfaces that connect to wiring where any portion of the wiring passes outside of the spacecraft faraday cage should not be damaged nor permanently degraded by exposure to ESD transients with a source equivalent to [MIL-STD-883L], class 2 (human body mode, 100 pF, 2000 volts, 1500 ohm).  

Note: [MIL-STD-883L] Class 2 envelopes the worst case expected cable discharge voltage and energy. The prime is responsible for defining any MPM interfaces that meet these criteria.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.4.9

Exposed dielectric surfaces and electrically isolated conductive surfaces, such as clamps, inserts, or other small components should be permitted provided that the total surface area does not exceed 3 cm2. 

Note: Larger areas are permitted where it can be shown that any resulting discharges will not degrade operation of any spacecraft subsystems or equipment.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.4.10

A static discharge path should be provided for all ESD conductive materials.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.4.11

Unless otherwise required by this document, the DC resistance of such static discharge path(s) should not exceed 106 ohms measured between the ESD conductive surface and the spacecraft ground plane.

X

 

 

 

3.13.1.3.4.12

The MPM should not use anodized finishes on surfaces exceeding 3 cm2 and are either exposed to space or separated from space only by a thermal blanket.
