3.14.3

Design Analysis Requirements

 

 

 

 

3.14.3.1

Worst-Case Analysis

 

 

 

 

3.14.3.1.1.1

Worst-Case Analysis (WCA) should be performed on the MPM to verify the design would meet system performance specification over design life under worst-case conditions and tolerances (initial, aging, radiation, and temperature).

X

 

 

 

3.14.3.2

Worst-Case Circuit Analysis

 

 

 

 

3.14.3.2.1.1

Worst-Case Circuit Analysis (WCCA) should be performed to verify the circuitry within the MPM would work as intended given that each constituent part is subject to worst-case conditions and tolerances (initial, aging, radiation, voltages, timing, and temperature).

X

 

 

 

3.14.3.3

Reliability Analysis

 

 

 

 

3.14.3.3.1.1

Reliability analysis should be performed to calculate the probability of success of the MPM over its design or mission life based on failure rates of parts, taking into account of redundancy and cross-strapping provisions in the MPM.

X

 

 

 

3.14.3.4

Failure Modes and Effects Analysis

 

 

 

 

3.14.3.4.1.1

Failure Mode and Effect Analysis (FMEA) should be performed to verify the impacts of the MPM to the system based on various Modes and to identify Single-Point Failures of the MPM.

X

 

 

 

3.14.3.5

Single Event Effects

 

 

 

 

3.14.3.5.1.1

Single Event Effects (SEE) Analysis should be performed to evaluate solid-state devices used in the MPM design as to the rate at which they would experience Single Event Upsets (SEU), Single Event Transients (SET), or other responses to the proton or heavy-ion environment on orbit, and the related circuit-level effects.

X

 

 

 

3.14.3.6

Thermal Analysis

 

 

 

 

3.14.3.6.1.1

Thermal Analysis should be performed to predict the range of temperatures that the MPM would encounter at the unit baseplate, across the surfaces of the circuit cards or modules, individual component case temperatures, and junction temperature rise in solid-state components, and to produce the heat flux per area for the MPM.

X

 

 

 

3.14.3.7

Radiation and Life Analysis of Parts

 

 

 

 

3.14.3.7.1.1

Radiation and Life Analysis should be performed to determine part parameter variations over the life of the parts used in the MPM.

X

 

 

 

3.14.4

Failure Reporting and Corrective Action System (FRACAS)

 

 

 

 

3.14.4.1.1.1

Using a space qualified system, records of failures and corrective actions implemented should be maintained throughout developmental assembly and testing of MPM.

 

X

 

 

End of table.

7 APPENDIX C: MPM Unit Concept The information in this appendix is for an example of a non-redundant MPM housing concept. The non-redundant housing concept is preferred for reasons associated with manufacturing and reducing schedule impacts during equipment and vehicle testing.

The MPM should be comprised of a SpaceVPX compliant chassis with SpaceVPX compliant modules. The figure below depicts a front view on the left and a rear view on the right.

The front view (left) depicts five (5) SpaceVPX modules (shown in blue) and two (2) spare SpaceVPX slots (shown in green). The housing contains what is referred to as the Basic-portion and the Switch-portion. In this concept, with respect to the front view from left to right, the first two single-wide slots are for the Switch-portion. The remaining 5 slots (3 single-wide, 2 double-wide) are for the Basic-portion.

For security purposes, the unit housing provides signaling isolation between the Basic- and Switch--portions. This also enables the high-speed Switch circuitry (and its internal Switch interface cabling) to be located in a space that is extended behind the Switch-portion modules (on the left) and widening to over half the width of the MPM at the rear. This effective volumetric extension of the Switch-portion within the chassis permits the Switch high-speed I/O circuit board to be located closer to its external interface connectors and provides space for easier external interface cable manual connection and removal.

From a unit external interface perspective, there are interface connections at the front and the rear of the MPM concept shown above. On the front view (left) there are accommodations for seven (7) SpaceVPX modules. The two modules on the left (#1 & #2) are within the Switch-portion and the five on the right (#3 - #7) are for the Basic-portion.

Within the Switch-portion, slot #1 is a single-wide power supply module and slot #2 is a spare single-wide SpaceVPX slot (potentially for a cyber related function).

Within the Basic-portion of the MPM, slot #3 is a single-wide SpaceVPX processor module. Slot #4 is single-wide module with a double-wide face plate used to accommodate twelve (12) SpaceWire connectors (for payloads). Slot #5 is a single-wide module with a double-wide face plate used to accommodate C&DH discrete signals for twelve (12) payloads (3 payloads per connector, harness would provide individual payload interface signal breakout). Slot #6 is a spare single-wide SpaceVPX slot. Slot #7 is a single-wide power supply module for the Basic-portion.

At the rear of the MPM (picture at right) there are additional interface connectors. The twelve (12) larger connectors at the right are for the MPM to payload high-speed interface (currently ETH fat-pipe). The medium and smaller size connectors at the upper left are used for the Host System A-side Discrete signals and SpaceWire, respectively. The medium and smaller size connectors at the middle left are used for the Host System B-side Discrete signals and SpaceWire, respectively. The medium size and smaller connectors at the bottom left rear of the MPM are used for the MPM-to-MPM Discrete signals and SpaceWire, respectively.

The dimensions of the single-thread MPM chassis depicted above are 15.5 length, 13.3 width (side-to-side, across visible modules), and 10.1 height. The mass is approximately 31 kilograms (~70 pounds).
